Choices: <n>A: washing machine <n>B: space shuttle <n>C: blender <n>D: disneyland <n>E: surface of earth.<n><n>#### Response: There are many appliances and devices out that can be described to use water and soap, including surface of earth, blenders, disneyland, washing machine, space shuttle, and earth.<n>##### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>## Instructions to write a short response:<n>Complete the following short response task. This task is based on the following input.<n><n>### Input<n>The students in Mary's class found an insect in the grass outside of the classroom during their walk to school. They counted their bugs and found the following:  <n><n>Mary has 4 bugs.  <n>Janet has 7 bugs.  <n>Kate has 7 bugs.<n><n>### Task<n>Write a sentence to answer the following question for the students in the scene.<n><n>### Solution to Task Instructions<n>Write a sentence to explain that Mary has 4+7 - Kate's 7 = <<4+7-7=5>>5 bugs<n><n>### Answer:<n>Mary has 5 bugs.<n><n>## Instrucciones para escribir una respuesta corta:<n>Complete the following task. Acorde con lo siguiente:<n><n>### Instrucción<n>Mary, Janet, y Kate encontraron una boca en el césped de la parte trasera de la escuela durante su caminata cada mañana. Los estudiantes contaron sus babosas y encontraron:  <n><p><n>Mary tiene 4 babosas.  <n>Janet tiene 7 babosas.  	<n>Kate tiene 7 babosos.  <n></p><n><p><n>La cuestión es:  	</p><n><h3>¡Ahora escríbelo!</h3><n><p>¡Vaya y dídelo a estos chicos!</p><n><n>### Reseña<n><n>Sólo necesitamos un símbolo de matemáticas. Para calificar, hay que especificar el sím
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The whole family was playing cards, they were full of joy and what? Choices:  A: sadness B: happiness C: amusement D: losing money E: anger<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### E<n><n>### Instructions:Choose and label a picture that corresponds to the given text.<n><n>### Text:Dressed in a gown and tiara, Julissa walked gracefully onto the stage. "Hi, I'm your emcee and contestant number 1...1...1...," she recited. "I'm here to compete for the crown of Miss Fancy!"<n><n>### Rationales:This text describes Julissa as entering a pageant.<n><n>#### Crowned in a gown<n><n>### Instructor:Please show me what you learned on your paper yesterday.<n><n>### Rationale:The Instructor asked the student to explain the results they obtained from the paper she wrote.<n><n>#### I learned the result was 2<n><n>### Instinctive Reasoning Tasks#<n><n>In instinctive reasoning tasks, the student needs to analyze data and perform some mental computations to arrive at an answer.<n><n>These are the types of questions where the instructor provides a list of tasks or instructions. The student will be asked to perform only one task for each example.<n><n>Examples could involve choosing data from a chart, determining the range of a list, determining the smallest or largest number in an interval, determining the average of a given list, or something similar.<n><n>The student may also be asked to perform two or more tasks for multiple examples.<n><n>### Inputs:Today’s math test includes 10 multiple-choice problems and 4 free response questions. You will have 85 minutes to complete it.<n><n>#### 54. I am going to assign a 3-to-5 sentence summary of the text. You will have 20 minutes to complete it. Here is a rubric for the assignment.<n><n>![Slide 1]<n><n>### How many possible 3-to-4 choices is there for example 54?<n><n>#### 1<n><n>### Example 40 asks the student to select the answer to the questions above in order to make a mental calculation and find the number of pizzas sold and the number of pencils left.<n><n>### How do you know which answer to select to complete the task?<n><n>#### 2<n><n>## Inputs:<n><n>### Input 48
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where does a spoon go on one side of a plate? Choices:  A: bowl of soup B: serving dish C: table setting D: placemat E: glass of iced tea<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. A B C D E<n>#### Others<n>Answer: Others<n><n>### Input :An apple tree produces 70 apples, an orange tree produces 28 oranges, a lemon tree produces 48 lemons, an avocado tree produces 52 avocados, and an orange tree is 5 times as tall as a lemon tree. If apples, oranges, lemons, and avocados have a total mass of 40 pounds, how tall is the avocado tree?<n><n>### Response<n>An apple tree produces 1 apple + 1 apple = <<1+1=2>>2 apples.<n>An orange tree produces 3/5 apples + 7/8 apples = <<3/5+7/8=2>>2 oranges (or 2+2=<<2+2=4>>2 oranges).<n>The lemon tree produces 2/3 apples + 1/8 apples + 1 apple = 2/3 * 2+1/8 * 2 = <<2/3*2+1/8*2=6+1/8=6+1/2=3+1/2>>2-1/2 lemons (or 4 lemons).<n>The avocado tree produces <<4>>2/3 times more apples than an orange tree, therefore <<2/3>>1/2 apple * 5 >>6 avocados).<n>The avocados have a weight of 28 pounds.<n>The apples weigh 40 pounds.<n>So, the total weight of apples and avocados is 40 pounds + 28 pounds = <<40+ 28= 68>>68.<n>(Their total weight is therefore 2/3 times the weight of apples 1/2 times the weight of the avocados + 1/8 times the weight of oranges = 68 ).<n>#### 68<n>Answer: 68<n><n>### Input<n>A boy has 36 marbles. He gives 7 marbles to a friend. How many marbles does he have left?<n><n>### Rationale<n>Input: The number of marbles he has left is 36 marbles - 7 marbles = <<36-7=2

Choices:  A: infect B: reproduce C: mutate D: eat food E: make computer malfunction<n><n>### Response:		<n>  ## Input:What does a computer virus primarily do to a computer?<n><n>  ## Choices:  A. infect B. reproduce C. mutate D. eat food E. make computer malfunction<n>   <n>  ## Answer:  A. infected<n>  ## Rationale: viruses only infect cells with their genetic material.<n>  ## If it reproduces, it will not infect a computer and therefore it does not eat it.<n>  ## E: make a computer malfunction; B: reproduce<n>  <n>### Input: In a science class, the students made a poster for the science show. The number of girls in the class was three times times higher than the number of boys. There were 5 more boys than girls. If there were 31 of each kind of poster, how many in all?<n>  ## Choices A)280 B)149 C)25 D)35 E)299<n><n>### Rationale: B. 150<n><n>  ## Number of boys = 31x5 + 5 = 31*5+5 = 155<n>  ## Number of girls = 31x3 + 1 = 31*3+1 = 94   <n>  ## Total = 155+94 = 25*3 = 55 + 1 = 56       <n>  ## Thus number of posters = 56 = 2*(23)<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program that takes in the following information:<n>  \_\_ Input:1001395230,2720,466033731,3610,769031084\_\_<n>What are the numbers 39073, 39167, and 75485?<n>You will need to use variables, math equations, and logical operators to write the program.<n>You will only need to solve the first sub-case of this problem. You do not need to create a function.<n>For example, you might write something like:<n><n>\_\_ <n>import java.util.*;<n>import java.awt.*;<n>import java.io.*;<n>  <n>public class Program<n>{<n>   public static
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is a place that might not always have a queen? Choices:  A: bee hive B: england C: castle D: deck of cards E: chess game<n><n>### Response:		E = E, because a chess game doesn't always have a queen.<n><n>### Inputs: What is not a possible answer for what time it was ten minutes ago? Choices:<n><n>	 ● One hour previously<n>	 ● Three month previously<n>	 ● Five years previously<n>	 ● Never<n> <n>A: B, because a clock can't have ten minutes ago, it can only have minutes to go.<n>B: A, because it must be hours to go, not hours previously.<n>C: D, because you can't have something in the past five years ago.<n>D: C, because a clock is counting.<n>E: B, because a chess clock is not counting time for a game.<n><n>	 ●	B is correct<n>	 ●	A is incorrect<n><n>### Input A:<n><n>	 20 + (x - 7) - (x - 8) = 76<n><n>	 29 - x + x = 30<n><n>### Response<n><n>	 98 - (20 + (x + 7) - (4 + 7) <n><n>A: - 98 + 20 + x + 7 + (7 + 4) = 113 is correct.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>	 99 - ((20 + (x-7) - (x-8) ) + 113 = 76<n>	 99 + (x - 6) (x - 7 )<n>	 100 + x^2 - 106<n><n>### Input B:<n><n>	 13 + (y - 7) - ((v - y) + 5) = 50<n><n>	 79 + 2x - (20 - x) = 99<n><n>	 66 + (x - 2) (60 - 2x - 2)<n><n>### Answer B<n><n>	 65 + ((y - 2 ) - x) (x - 69) (6-x) (60 -2x-2)<n><n>## Part 2. <n>Find the answer and put the name of the problem as an answer.<n>Do this twice.<n><n>### One problem<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What place is not interesting to children? Choices:  A: classroom B: toy store C: school D: soccer game E: dinner<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice A<n><n>### Response<n>B<n><n>### Choice A<n><n>### Choices B<n><n>### Choicd E<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a number sentence that expresses the relationship, which accurately explains the difference in size between the group of students and the total number of students.<n><n>### Input<n>5.5 billion people attend a concert in New York on Earth Day. All 17,500,000 students from each state attend the concert. How many students are there in total in the concert?<n><n>### Solution<n>A number sentence that expresses that the school day is not interesting to children is Choice E.<n><n>### Choiced E<n><n>### Answer<n>5,500 B<n><n>### Summing up<n>There are 5,500,17,50 million children present in the school concert.<n>The population of the people attending the concert is 5,50 x 1,75,00,0017,50.<n>The total number children present in the Earth’s school concert is 10,18,50,000,560.<n>If the total number of the students present in the 50 states of the USA is 17,53,000,175, 000,00,17.500, 000.<n>Then, the total of the children present in this school concert is 1,732.10.<n><n>### References<n>1. https://www.ets.org/gre/revised_general_test/prepare/released_questions/question_09.pdf<n>2. https://www.wmich.edu/sites/default/files/uploads/wmichedu/testingcenter/files/2019-03/3712%20-%20GRE%20Multiple%20Choice%20Example.pdf<n>3. https://www.toppr.com/guides/toppr-foundation-prep-course-2022/math-algebra-and-numbers/solving-equations/solving-inclusive-inequalities-1

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:How can you get in shape if there is no land nearby? Choices:  A: swim B: jog C: excercise D: work out E: rock climb<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input<n>Which equation model has an ordered pair that is (4,12)? Choices:  A:(x+12)(x-7) B:(x-6)(x+8) C:(x-2)(x-4) D:(x-6)(2x+7)<n><n>### Response<n>B<n><n>### InputWhich equation model has a slope of -1/2? Choices:  _______ A:(x-12)/(x-6) B:(4-(x-2))/(2-(x+1)) C:(x+5)/(2x-5) D:(x+2)(x-3)/(x-6)(x-7)<n><n>## InputWhich equation model is equivalent to (y- 17) + (x- 8)? Choices:  ___________ A: -(y+17) + (y-8) B: -y+y B -(y-8)+(y-17) C: -(y-17) + (8-y) D: -(y-15) + (y-17)<n><n>##OutputIn each table shown on the graph, which column shows the equation you need to solve to find your answer? Which is true?<n><n>### Your option<n>C<n><n>### Your logic<n>The length is not equal to the width, therefore the length is not equal to<n>```<n><n>### Next response<n>Next choice: D<n><n>### Your Rational<n>The length is not the width, therefore the ratio would be less than 1 because the length is greater than the<n>width.<n><n>### Correct Responses<n><n>* Answer: B<n><n>Input:<n>```<n>In an old-fashioned farmhouse, the family used a large garden to grow its fruits and vegetables. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. He worked there for 5 years and then went on vacation to Mexico. He came back in 1987, and has worked there ever since. How many years did he work at the bakery?<n><n>#### 25<n><n>### Your Response<n><n>The number of year Ricky worked at the bakery was 1982+5= <<1982+ 5=1987>>1987. When he went on vacation to mexico, the number of the years he worked there was 1987-5 = <<1987- 5=1992>>1992. When he came back, he has started work there and his total number of years there is 1992 + 1987 =<<1992+ 1987= 3769>>3769.<n>#Input is 1982, How many years does he work there since he returned after 5 years?<n>The number of year he works at the bakery from 1987 to 1992 is <<1987+1987-1985+1986>>+1985 1985 years.  When he has started work there, the number of the year was 1992, so the answer is 1990+1992.<n>#Now write the question<n>#### 1990<n><n>### What is the height of the baker? Input: At a bakery, a man bought a loaf of bread

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What does someone want when having fun with their friends and trying to fit in? Choices:  A: being understood B: beer C: playing around D: hug E: visiting friends<n><n>### Response:		B, Beer<n><n>### Explanation:<n>  B: Beer<n>A: Being understood<n>B: Beer<n>C: Playing around<n>D: Hug<n>E: Visiting friends<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:It was a vast complex, the launch pad was just one part of what? Choices:  A: movie B: cape kennedy C: space center D: military installation E: spaceship centre<n><n>### Response:		<n>It was a vast complex. The launch pad was just one of the parts of this complex.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>A vast complex is described by the verb “was” so we know this “was” a vast complex. This verb tells us that this complex is currently not vast, it was a vast complex. Then, the question states the “launch pad” was just one part of this complex. The launch pad is a specific part of a vast complex so only it’s part was the launch pad. Now, because the launch pad is just one part of the vast complex, we know that the complex cannot be the launch pad, it is a vast complex. This leaves movie, cape kennedy, space center, military installation, and spaceship centre. Spaceship centre is out because we knew the launch pad was “just one part of the vast launch” so it is an inaccurate option to fill in the blank, so we must choose an option that isn’t spaceship centre. Military installation and cape kennedy are both military launch pads. We only know that the question means the launch pad, which is a specific part of the vast launch. Military installations and Cape kennedy don’t only mean one specific part of their respective objects. Therefore, we have to be more general. We don’t know the size or the exact location of the launch, we only know the location is Florida and that it is vast, so the one part can’t be the one of the launch complex. Therefore we know the launch complex is not a movie. It can’t be a space centre either because we know it is vast, not tiny, and vast doesn’t match up with space centre. Therefore, the launch pad is just “one part” of the vast, so it is a movie.<n>#### Movie<n>Answer: Movie<n><n>### Input 2:<n>Jenny has written 2 less messages than Shyla. Jenny has written half as many messages as Seth. How many messages did Shyla write?<n>Rationales::<n><n>If you multiply the first number by 2, then take away it from another number by subtracting it, you will get the answer. This way, we know that Shyla wrote 18 more messages than Jenny and 4 less messages than Seth. <n>```<n> 2*(Seth's number) = Sh
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is "B".<n><n>#### Rationale:<n>"He wore heels." means that he wore the wrong shoes. He walked all day and now he has "Moving Forward" on his heels and "Feet" on his toes.<n><n>#### Other responses:<n><n> - "Exercise" is incorrect since "he walked all day".<n><n> - "Locomotion" is incorrect since it refers to the ability to move.<n><n> - "Feet" is incorrect because this refers to the foot part of the body, as opposed to toes.<n><n> - "Blisters" is incorrect because the correct response does not refer to pain or discomfort.<n><n>### Input:"The red and the yellow bus are leaving in minutes!" say the school bus director to all the children. But then a child says: "Oh no! I left my book and lunch bag on the bus! And I am leaving in about half an hour." How long before both buses arrive at school?" Choices: A: 0 minutes since I don’t know when the red bus is arriving. B: 15 minutes C: 14 minutes since I don’<n><n>### Response:"A".<n><n>#### Rationales:<n>Since I don't know when the red and yellow bus are arriving, there is no way to know for certain when they will arrive. However, the child will be leaving in about 30 minutes, so it is likely that she or he will arrive around 0:30 (15 minutes before/after buses arrive).<n><n>#### Other responses:"B":<n>The child would have to leave 0 minutes after arriving (if leaving at the same time as the buses arrives) and 15 minutes before the bus arrives (if leaving 0:15 before).<n><n>#### "C":<n>14 minutes is not possible since there are only 15 minutes until all buses arrive at school.<n><n>#### All other responses:<n>The child will be late if leaving at or 0:00 (noon) or later.<n><n>###Input: A baker makes pies for the grocery store. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How much must you make if every month you need to make an additional $1500.<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>```text<n>Made money $m \times 2% \times m = I <n>    I > 0<n>     => m > (I^2)/2<n>m = 0.25 * 2/25 (m > 0.5/5) m =   0.5/5<n><n>```<n><n>## Answer:  $ m = 0.5/9 $<n><n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:A shower is an expected amenity when you reserve a what? Choices:  A: gy mnasiu m B: motel room C: seashore D: bath room E: locker room<n><n>### Response:		Gy mnasiu m<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Gy mnasiu m: gy mnasiu = <<gy+mnasiu=c>> C is expected when you reserve a room<n>mnasiu is the opposite of expected.<n>Gy is a verb.<n>m is a 3 digit number.<n><n>Input: You can rent a room or a locker. Some people like a shower. So, a shower is an expected room amenity. Is a shower expected when you reserve a locker?<n>Rationales There are 3 types of accommodations for rooms<n>A: gy mnasiu u room<n>B: gy mnasiu luem room<n>C : gy mnasiu m room<n>D: gy mnasiu o room<n>E: gy mnasiu um room<n><n>**gy mnasiu = <<c>> C is expected, expected amenity<n>c = A: gy mnasluem u room= <<gy+mnasluem*u+room=B>> B room<n>c = B: gy mnaslu m room=<<gy+mnaslu* m+room=C>> C room<n>c = C: gy mnasiu room=<<gy+nmnaisi* room=D>> D room<n>c = D: gy mnasiu om room=<<gy+ n.mnasiu * o.m+room=1>> room<n>c= E: gy mnasiu un room= <<gy+mnassiu_ *un+room=1>> 1 room**<n><n>Therefore, a shower is a expected amenity when you rent a hotel room (gy mnasiu m room).<n>A locker has an amenity called mnasiu.<n>Input: Is a bath, not a shower, expected when you reserve a motel room?<n>Rationales A: gy mnaslau u room<n>B:gy mnaslu m room<n>C: gy mnasiu  um room<n><n>D: gy n.m nasium room<n><n>E: gy m nasiu um room<n><n>If gy mnaslaim= <<gy+mnsailum == C room, gy+mnsailum+u=D room> Gy mnaslau u room and E gy mnuasi u room, then gy mnaslaum room is the opposite of expected and expected amenity. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where can you store you tent and keep it on your person? If you use a symbol (such as a slash), do not forget to fill in the numerator and denominator as shown.<n><n>### Question 2:<n>Input: Janine is a tennis fanatic who has 96 less tennis rackets than her sister, Coco. On the other hand, Coco has only half as many rackets as her twin brother, Devin. How many total tennis rackets do the three children have?<n><n>### Rationale: Coco has 96 - 96/2 = <<96-96/2=48>>48 less rackets than her sister Janine.   Devin has 0 - 96/4 = <<0-96/4=24>>24 less rackets than his twin sister Coco.  Janine has 96 + 24 + 48 + 4 = <<96+24+48+4=174>>174 rackets.  So, Coco has 48,  Janine has 174,  and Devin has 240.  48 + 174 + 240 = <<48+174+240=462>>462 total rackets.<n>#### 462<n>`<n>Answer: 462<n><n>------- Instalation completed. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		A, D, or both:  cook dinner, eat, back to work, make food, go back to work because the cupboards were baren<n><n>### Instructions:Answers as many of the questions as you can without reviewing any of the solution procedures.<n><n>Question: Which one of the following is not a rational number? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you have curiosity about something but cannot leave your house? Which word best represents the combination of luck and dedication to improving? Input:  A: haters B: surprise C: compliments D E: solution<n>Rationales: Luck plays a big role when the person is in a bad situation or not. The person with luck will be in a bad situation and will not be able to work. Dedication is the work of a person who does nothing when he or she has bad luck. Dedication alone does not work. The person who is most successful has all of his attention and time.<n>```<n>Luck, dedication, and the ability to find solutions in bad situations are not different. All of them are luckier or luckier.<n><n>Solution: Focus and work for improvement<n>```<n><n>#### 25<n>Answer: Focus and work to improve<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What chore might a child have to do after breakfast, before getting on the bus? Choices:  A: drop out of school B: ask questions C: enter school D: wash dishes E: read book<n><n>### Response:		A:<n>Rationales: Drop out of school means leaving school while not completing the class; so, it’s not a correct answer.<n>Enter school means entering the school premises; so, it’ an incorrect answer.<n><n>The question asks for the child to do a chore after breakfast, before getting to school. Therefore, an answer that is in the order of the words given – “after breakfast, before getting to the school” means “before getting to the school” is the correct answer.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: "Before getting to the school"<n><n>### Input;Janet has 9 cards, more than brenda. Mara has 20 cards, twice as many as Jane. How many cards do we have in all, if Mara has 210 cards less than 343?<n> <n>### Response;;<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>Rationale 1:<n>A question in Math is always asked to find the answer to a given statement.<n>And the answer can only be a whole number (an integer)<n>A given number of 210 and the subtraction of 343 leads to negative answer, which is an incomplete answer to the problem. So, it’s considered as an incorrect response.<n><n>Rationale 2:<n>A question in math, in this case, is always asking the given situation to answer the question.<n>A question asks the given answers to be combined into a whole number, an integer to solve the question.<n><n>## Answer: 210 less than 344<n><n><n>## Solution Code<n><n>{% highlight python %}<n>def check_answer(answer):<n><n>    return "That would be correct if there were not negative numbers in this problem"<n><n>def tester(statement):<n>    if (statement[4] == '.') :<n>        return "Another negative digit in this part of the problem. Please use'+ '."<n><n>def check_
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where can someone view a county highway as a line? Choices:  A: from the sky B: map C: cross counties by car D: country E: michigan<n><n>### Response:		The only place one can view a county highway as line is from the sky.<n>Answer<n>

So you are trying to access/index a `string` with no index or integer value.<n><n>You need to convert the string to an `int` first to access the `index`. Here is an example:<n><n>\begin{code}<n>>>> word = ['red','green','yellow']<n>>>> length = len(word)-1<n>>>> index = word.index('green')<n>>>> index<n>0<n>>>><n>\end{code}.

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is another term for instituting civil action? Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is confusion<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Instituting civil action means starting a legal process.<n>A court or the police force may institute civil or criminal action.<n><n>### The second character in the password is a question mark. It acts as a sign to alert you that there is at least one spelling error in the password. In order to avoid inadvertently clicking on a question when it does not need to be there, please review your password carefully and note that is will be case sensitive and upper and lower case letters may be used.<n><n>### For example, if we enter _q_uestion_m_ark___1111 in the password field.<n><n>### Note that passwords for this class were not created to be too long, but passwords were also not intended to be too short.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would I put a rosebush if I did not have any containers to store it in? Choices:  A: flower garden B: garden center C: pot D: pot E: formal garden<n><n>### Response:		Put the rosebush in a flower garden.<n><n>### Input A:  The sum of two numbers is 75. 25 is one less than one-half of their difference.  What are the two numbers?<n><n>### Rationale:<n>25 = 75 - 1/2 (75 - 1).<n>75 = 75 + 1/2(75 - 1)<n><n>#### Answer: 50 and 25<n><n>### Input B:  A store sells 13 pairs of black socks for $24.99 each. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Sarah opened his chest and found a second heart.  Her patient might not be what? Choices:  A: istanbul B: animal C: antique shop D: human being E: bedroom<n><n>### Response:		This does not look like a heart from a normal human being and is not in a human body. It is an antique artifact.<n><n>### Answer:D<n><n>### Question:Sarah opened her chest and found a __________ heart.<n><n>### A: istanbul<n><n>### B: animal<n><n>### C: antique shop<n><n>### D: human being<n><n>### E: bedroom<n>

Choices: 1: 4 <n><n>### Response A:Select the appropriate choice given.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Instructions:Write an appropriate math statement.<n><n>### A: Which of the choices is greater?<n><n>Answer: 1: 3<n><n>### Input B: Which choice is the multiple of 1? Choices: 3: 7<n><n>### Response B:Select the appropriate choice.<n><n>#### Response Explanation:<n>Since the question provides the numbers 3, 7 and 5, you have to select from the choices. However, if you check the question, it's easy to find out the answer and you may not need to choose anything.<n><n>Since the answer is 1, 7 is the multiple of 7, and 3 is the multiple of 5.<n><n>### C: Which choice is the least number that will not divide evenly with 13? Choices: 9: 5<n><n>### Response C:Select the multiple.<n><n>#### Response 9:Explanation:<n>The question says, which choice is the least number and it's not required to look for the greatest number that will divide 13. So you need to find which one of the numbers will not divide 13, so 3 will not divide evenly to 13

Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where is a lion likely to live? Choices:  A: veldt B: ocean C: savannah D: africa E: jungle<n><n>### Response:		 None of E and none of A<n><n>### Explanation:  A and B are not likely to be a lion's habitat.<n><n>### Input:: Which of the following two choices is greater?  Choices:  A. greater than B. not greater than C. equal<n><n>### Rationales:  A greater than B<n><n>### Examples to show a sequence of mathmatical statements:<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Sequence<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>### Answer<n><https://math.lajoya-isd.org/math_portal/modules/portal/content/13670/13686/lesson19.html><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Everybody raised a drink and cheered, they were doing what? Choices:  A: were thirsty B: toasting C: getting drunk D: refreshment E: celebrating<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### What was the most common reason you raised a drink? (Why the hell did I even write this)<n><n>**Explanation:** The common reason that you raise a drink is to toast.<n>It is stated in the input that everybody raised a drink and cheers. <n>Therefore, they are all toasting.<n><n>### Incorrect:<n><n>```<n><n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n>'''<n>Write the code below and name the file <n>'''<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: Everybody raised a drink and ________, they were doing what?<n>Rationales :<n>Choices: A: Were thirsty<n>B: Toasting<n>C: Getting drunk<n>D: Refreshment<n>E: Celebrating<n><n><n>### Answer:<n><n>```<n># -*- Coding: utf-8 - *-<n><n><n><n>from functools import wraps<n><n>class Timer:<n>    def start(self):<n>        self.startTime = time.time()<n>    def stop(self):<n>        time_used = time.time() - self.startTime<n>        self.total_time = self.total_time + time_used<n><n>class TimerizedFunc(object):<n>    @wraps(func)<n>    def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs):<n>        with Timer() as timer:<n>            return func(*args, **kwargs)<n>        <n>    def __init__(self, func):<n>        self.func = func<n>        <n>    def timeit(self, *args,**kwargs):<n>        return TimerizedFunc(*args,**kwargs)(self.func)<n>            <n>def aaa(n):<n>    if n % 2 == 1:<n>        return n + 'is odd'<n>    else:<n>        return n  + 'is even'    <n>def bbb(n):<n>    print(aaa(n))<n>##<n>aaa(5)<n>b = TimerizedFunc(bbb)<n>a = b(5)<n>print('Total Time', a.timeit(3))<n>print('Average', a.timeit() / 3)<n>print('Minimum', a.timeit().min())<n>print('Maximum', a.time it().
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses.
