There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Choices:  A: injury B: death C: playing uno D: coma E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		You think death is an option, not sure I wanna do it again!<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the multiple choice question.<n>### Input: Alannah, Dylan, and Zoe are planning a party. They need supplies.  Alannah decides to bring 3 items to the party. Dylan decides to bring 2 items to the party. Alannah’s items are twice as many as Dylan’s items. How many items do they all have in all?<n>### Rationales: Alannah’s first item is twice her second item.<n>All items will be 2 +1 +2 = <<2+1+2=5>>5items.<n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Instructons: Answer the multiple choice Question.<n><n>### Input 6<n>A.  There are 1526 people at the circus.  There are 52 children less than adults at the circus. How many people are there at the circus?<n><n>### Rationals Answer: 1526-52<n><n>### The number of children is 52 and there are 52 more then adults 52+52 = 104<n><n>### Answer: 1568<n><n>### Input The cake is 2/3 of the pie<n>1. The pie is 11/4 times of the cake and the cake is 14/8 of the pie<n>2. The pie is 2 1/4 times of cake and the cakes is 3 1/2 of the pie<n>3. The cake is half of the pie and the cake is a third of the pie<n>4. The cake is 1 and 2/3 of a pie and the pie is 4 and 1/3 of a cake<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If you did well on the test, you might get an A as a what? Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationale:Correct answer = A:See Work<n><n>### Rationales:C:Quiz<n><n>### Input B:Practice<n>(Work -> Practice)<n><n>### Input C:Test Correction<n><n>### Input D:School Grade<n><n>### Input E:Homework<n><n>### Input A:See work<n><n>Correct answer = A<n><n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:When people discover something new while chatting with friends, why are they likely to continue talking? Choices:  A: agreement B: to fill their time C: discomfort D: misunderstanding E: learning about<n><n>### Response:		Choice: D<n><n>---<n>#### Extra Credit<n>Below is an instruction that describes an activity. Write an explanation that describes the process.<n><n>### A task.<n><n>### Activity:<n>Create a diagram.<n><n>#### Questions to consider:<n>- What are the two main ideas being communicated in the chart?<n>- What is the conclusion you draw from the chart?<n>- Do you have any questions or comments about the chart?<n><n>---<n>#### Instruction:Create the following table.<n>Answer the questions and use the information to create your chart below.<n><n>How big is my family? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Janet knew she was dying from her injuries because she could feel herself doing what? Choices:  A: sleeping longer B: getting cold C: death and decay D: change of color E: stop breathing<n><n>### Response:		Janet was dying because she knew she was getting cold.<n><n>### Input:(Janet knew she was DYING because she could feel herself getting COLD)<n><n>### Response:(Janet could feel herself DYING because she was getting COLD)<n>

Which answer is greater, 23 or 30?<n>### Response:   <n>#### Choice:A<n>### Input:Which expression shows a set that contains 4 and is not empty?<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Instructions:Answer each question:<n>#### 4<n><n>## Input:In 56 + 19 + 24, what is the value of the digits in the + symbol?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>In 56, the digit in the + is the sum of digits of 5 and 6, which is 11.<n>24 + 24 = 48 + 24 =56<n>In 19, the digit in the  is the sum of digits in 1 and 9, which is 10.<n>So, the value of digit in + symbol for 56 + 24 + 19 is 10, which is the sum of digits 5, 6, 2 and 4.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 48<n><n>### Instructon:Add<n><n>### Instraction:Add.<n><n>### Explication:Answer the following question using a letter from the set A, C, E, I, or O.<n><n>#### O<n>Answer: <n><n>### Rent a bike!<n>## Input:When you rent a bike, do you want to ride in a lake, or the park?<n>#### 3<n>Answer:<n>### Instruction.Write the value of the digit in the - symbol:<n>#### 21-4<n>Answer:8<n><n>### Rationale<n>The value of digit in - symbol is sum of digits at both sides of -.<n>Sum of digits at the left side is 2 + 1 = <<2+1=3>>3.<n>Sum of digits are 2 at the right side is 2.<n>

Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>Let the surface of earth be the grass.<n>The rest area is not within it.<n>If state park is within it, then supermarket is within it.<n>State park is within the grass.<n>The same is for garden.<n>Garden is within the grass. This answers choice A.<n><n>### Response<n>Let the rest area be the grass.<n>If state park and supermarket are within it, then both supermarket and rest area are within it.<n>If supermarket is within it, then rest area is within it.<n>Both supermarket and rest area will be within it. Therefore, supermarket and rest area is within the grass. Answer choice A.<n><n>*Example Instruction:*<n>#### Input:Find as many fractions as possible that are between 0.1 and 0.5, but they can’t involve 0.3 as a numerator or denominator. <n>#### Input:Find all the fractions you can that total 0.75 and equal 5/15.<n>#### Input:What kinds of fractions can these numbers make? (6/2 and 3/2)  What does each fraction represent? <n>#### Response:  Let 6/2 and 1/3 be the fractions.<n>6/2 times 1/3 is not an integer and so must reduce to a fraction.<n>6/2 * 1/3 = 2/5 is not a fraction but rather a mixed number.<n>Thus, you have found three fractions from 0,1,5 and 2.<n><n>### Question:What fraction out of one half equals 0, ¼, 3/16, 7/​32, 101/​2048?<n>#### Response:<n>If 0, ¼ or 3/​16 divide equally into 1/2, there should be at least three options.<n><n>1. Since 0,1 cannot be divisible by whole numbers, it is not a fraction for this question.<n>2. Since 1/​8 is not a fraction, it is not a result for this question.<n>3. Since 3/16 does not go evenly into 1/2.<n>4. Since 7/​34 is not a fraction, this is not a result.<n>5. Since 101

Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What has a master of their craft done about that craft? Choices:  A: drill B: committed murder most vile C: bargemaster D: learn E: understand<n><n>### Response:		The master of craft must have an answer for their craft.<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input:"The more I think, the vaguer I get.""That was the most unexciting chili I've ever seen."<n>Beth and John are having lunch together. Choices: A: Beth's comment B: John's comment C: Beth's comment D: John's comment<n><n>### Response:"The more I think and the vaguer I become.""The chili was unexciting and plain."<n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input:[The story's about a family of frogs who find a magic lamp. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:He was a very sharp engineer, but when it came to the details his calculations could were often what? Choices:  A: complimentary B: inelegant C: ocean D: dull E: inaccurate<n><n>### Response:		Input:He was a _____ enginee <n><n>### Input is : He was a very sharp engineer<n><n>### Engineer<n>So, answer is 'A: complimentary'<n><n>Input: The sum of any two consecutive prime numbers must be _____? Choices: 1: odd2: even 3: composite 4: even and prime 5: odd and even<n><n>### Response to the correct answer<n>Input:The sum of any two consecutive number must be _________,choose one of the following:1: odd2:even3,composite4:even and prime5: odd and even <n><n>### Odd<n>Input: The sum is odd so the answer is 1 or even<n><n>### Given sum is even <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The electric motor powered many important things, including one if almost every house. In 6 games time, Allyson would complete all the games and win the game. The game was over, and Brenda lost the game.<n><n>#### Answer: B<n><n>The correct answer is B because: Brenda played 5 games which means the second student (Allyson) would have to play 6 games in order to win. Choices:  A: top of home B: older houses C: victorian house D: own home E: material<n><n>### Response:		<n>- Top of home<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A. Top of home: This is most likely to have items in an attic that have historical significance.<n><n>B. Older houses: This type of home must have items that are historical, though they are likely found in the home more than the attic since the home was likely made a while ago.<n><n>C. Victorian house: This type of home may not be as likely to have an attico with historical items, but it may still have these items.<n><n>D. Material: This is a more general answer because it is the owner's house and they may have these items. <n><n>E. Own home: This is a more open-ended answer since this may be the case in their own homes, but it may not be most common. <n><n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:How is someone who loves their TV likely to feel about their remote? Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n><n>### Response:		C: companionable<n><n>### Rationale:One can say that a person is attached to something when it is part of their every day life and they can't imagine life without it.  They won’t be able to function with it gone.  However, this is clearly not the case with a remote where one would imagine could throw it away if necessary.<n><n>Another type of relationship, one can describe as companionable, could be related to a person being happy that they found or purchased something that was useful.  This can be the case even if they knew it didn’t have to be purchased (a gift for example).    Or it could be that even if they no longer use it, they are happy/satisfied with what they have and don’t “need” more.<n><n>#### C<n><n>Answer: C<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What common chemical reaction is often used as a heat source? Choices:  A: coal or wood B: fire C: lava D: house E: solar energy<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you have done a previous lesson, you should know that a common chemical reaction is often called a combustion reaction. It contains a 2-carbonyl group with a hydrogen atom. This reaction is often used as fuel to heat homes or water. Another common chemical reaction is to oxidize a substance when it comes from the sun's light.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: A<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:John joined the army because he wanted to see the world. He wanted to finish the course but bad weather made. When is the next time that he play 12 holes again? Choices: A: two days B: Three days C: four days D: other<n><n>### Response : the next time that he can play 12 holes is tomorrow<n><n>### Answer : B<n><n>Input: When is the next time Jake will play 12 holes? The next time that Jake will play 9 holes is tomorrow. When is the next day that he can play 9 holes after tomorrow?<n>Rationales : The next time that he will play 12 hole will be next day ( 1=tomorrow, 2=next_day)<n><n>Next day that he can play after 2=tomorrow is = [1+1] -2= 0 - 2= -2<n><n>Having two options left now, next day is B. Next day that he can play is A.<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### What was the original price? A. 33 cents B. 49 cents. C. 79 cents. D. 96 cents. E. Choices:  A: street B: soccer field C: soccer game D: central park E: pool table<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:<n><n>Where do kids play soccer?<n><n>Choices<n><n>A, B, C, D, and E<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: soccer field<n><n>Input:<n><n>What do birds use sticks for?<n><n>Choices:<n><n>sticks, nests, houses<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: nests<n><n>Input:<n>When does a day begin at midnight?<n><n>Choices :<n><n>A, B<n><n>#### A<n>Because midnight marks a new day, and morning starts at the beginning of the day, at midnight.<n>#### B<n>Midnight is the 24th hour of the day, so it’s not at the beginning of the next day.<n><n>### Input<n><n><n>#### What do you do when the lights are out in the room of a friend?<n><n>#### Choices:<n><n>A, B C<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>you do when the lights out in the room of your friend<n><n>#### choose A<n>When my parents are asleep, I go down, flip the switch, and get out of there quickly!<n><n>#### Input<n><n>When is 5 times 8?<n><n>Choices A: five times eight<n><n>#### B: five times eight<n>#### C: five times eight<n>### Input:<n><n>My classmates have not been very generous with my fundraiser. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would a special ficus be found? Choices: A: a conductor B: a drummer C: a trumpet player D: a cellist E: a flutist<n><n>### Response<n> I would most likely hear a flutist or a flautist play a musical instrument during a musical concert. <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: On what date did the Declaration of Independence become official? Choices: A December 1st, 1771 B March 1st, 2018 C December 4th, 1776 D January 1st, 495 B.C E January 1st, A.D. 2016<n><n>### Response (3 characters)<n> I believe that the answer is  C December 4th, 1776<n><n>### Dem<n>### Response:<n>Answer is : C<n><n>### Instruct: <n>Input: In order to have a pink-colored rose, what are you missing the ingredient? Choices: A A water B red rose petals C white rose petals D a color-enhancing ingredient E pink rose petals<n><n>### Response <n> Answer is : D A color enhancing ingredient<n><n>### Dem:<n>Water does not make a petal pink, and pink has no white or red in the name.<n><n><n>In order to have a p.ink-colored rose there must be an ingredient that is pink.<n> <n> ##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Bob and Boris were standing in a queue at the grocery store.  They were standing in place.  The line was fast, but the children in front of them were loud.   They were what? Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>

Each time it is increased by 3, what is the height of the building?<n>Rationales:: 130 + (130 -3) = 130 + 127 -3 = 130 - 1 <=<<130-1=129>>129 feet.<n>For 129 feet, the next height is 129 + (129 - 3) = 129 + 126-3 = 129 - 1 <=<<+(-(-1)))>>< 129 -1 <==-129<n>Answer: 129 feet<n><n>Input: The number 13 + 2 x 6 + 8 = <<13+2x6+8=26>>26. Choices:  I: 1 year. II: 11 months. III: 12 months.  IV: 13 months.<n><n>### Response : <n>II<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: Jack, John, and Johnny played soccer against each other. Two were winners. Johnny’s team won, and John’s team lost. Jack’s team was the other of the losers. How many games were played altogether?<n>Rationales : If 1 game is played, Jack’s team is the winner.<n><n>If 2 games are played, Jack’s and Johnny’s teams both win or lose.<n>The other of the losers (John’s team) play with remaining one game. <n><n>If 3 games are played, Johnny’s team win and Jack’s team lose. John’s team play with remaining one game that is the other of the loser (John’s).<n><n>If 4 games are played, Johnny's team win and John's team both lose.<n><n>If 5 games are played, Johnny and Jack's team both win and John's loses.<n><n>Therefore, if 6 games are played, then they both win, the remaining one must be played with John's team as the loser.<n>So, If 6 games are played the winner are John and Johnny<n>And the loser is Jack.<n>Thus, They have played 6 games.<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input  :<n>If a number has the value of 3 more than another number, then it's value is<n><n>### Rationales  :<n>If the numbers are say `a` and `b`, then `a` + 3 = `c`.<n>`b` – (a + 3) = `d`<n>`c` = `a` + 2<n>`d` = `b` + 1<n><n><n>#### 10<n>Answer: 61<n><n>### Input<n>Eight friends arrived at a playground. Each friend played a sport of his or her choice: chess, s

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The cow would come outside even after the storm had passed, it wouldn't leave the what? Choices:  A: meat grinder B: stable C: red barn D: gate E: green field<n><n>### Response:		The cow would come outside even  after the storm had passed. The most logical answer would be option E, a green field.<n><n>Input: Toby has 3 blue cars. He takes one on the drive train. Three other cars are red. Two of the red cars can fit in the trunk. How many more red cars do they have after Toby takes the entire trunk?<n>Rationales Toby has 3 cars: blue car 1, blue car 2, blue car 3<n>Toby takes one of his blue cars = <<Take the blue car =1>>1<n>There are 3-1 = <<3-1=2>>2 blue cars left<n>Two of the red cars can use up the trunk, but we're assuming that the blue is the only blue in the drive.<n>Now Toby has two blue cars + 2 red cars = <<2+2=4>><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: Shauna is playing a game on her computer. She uses all her game credits. She has 15 games on her computer. Each of her computer games use 12 credits. What is the total cost of games in dollars and cents?<n>Rationales Shauna has 15 games = <<15=15>>15 games<n>Each game cost 12 credits = <<12=12>>12 credits<n>So, the total cost of each game was 12 * 15 games = 12 * 5 bucks =<n><<12*5=60>>6 credit<n><n>#### $60<n>Answer: $60<n><n>Input: Cindy and Javier play chess at the park. They play $5 a game. Once per day, they play three games. How much do they spend at the park in all?<n>Rationale There are 3 games played per day. With each game Cindy and Javer play $5 per game.<n>So, there is 3 games * $5 =<<3*5=3>>3 x 5 = 15 dollars. And there is a total of 15+15 = 30<n>#### $30<n>Answer: $30<n><n>Input: The new mall, in our city, is expanding. The manager of the new store says that they want

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is likely to be the goal of telling many people about a new organization? Choices:  A: accomplish B: learn about C: money D: notoriety E: religion<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n>Input: Choices: A: accomplish B: learning about C: money D.<n>notoriety E: religion Choice: A<n><n>### Input.<n>Given 12.93 kg of chocolate candies, the candies were sold. Each 12.9 g of chocolate candied costed $2.19 per 12.92 g on December 21st. The total cost was $216. During 1.86 g, the cost was $0.03. On December 22nd, 3.72 g were sold at $2.66 and $11.26 was earned. How many grams of chocolate candie were sold on December 23rd?<n>Rationales. The total cost was 216 + 0.03*(1.86) + (3.72) * 2.66 = <<216+0.03*(2.19+1.86+3.72)+(2.66)>>00.03219+1-86+3.82660.032.060.03826.00382.063 = << 211>>2 16288952030.630.033.930.013.9326.000.023.911.3611.8622.160.236.3722.362.388.060.9726.0029.0426.372.386.0400.977.2600.238.0636.020300-68.066.040.977-26.007.260.238-4\0.040036.02-26.0-0.00.239.04 \02.38-2000 0.000 017.9
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Therefore, the question has to be false)<n><n>### Choices:  A:(all the girls + all the boys are odd) B:(all the girls are even but all the odd numbers are boys) C:(all the girls are divisible by 2 but all the odd numbers aren’t divisible by two.)<n>D(All the girls are even but odd number are boys)<n><n>### Instrector Explanation: (All options except C seem to be logically correct. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:A water spout was seen in the ocean off the coast of what? Choices:  A: florida B: basement C: sink D: beach E: fountain<n><n>### Response:		<n>What is the correct answer to the above question?<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input::Cameron needs the car for a ride later tonight. Is the tire flat or not? Choices: A: not B: yes C: flat<n><n>### Response::<n>What is the correct response to the above question? Is the tire flat of not?<n>#### A<n><n>Answer: A<n>

A bookstore is a town which includes many things like Magazines, Carpets, Phones, etc. 13 / 10<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following open-ended question.13. 10 / 13<n><n>### Input 10: The United States Constitution establishes the form of American government. 13: The Federalist Papers explain the reasons behind some of the features of the Constitution. Write a response that explains the feature of the Constitution (explain why it should be in the Constitution) from one of the Federalist Papers and then gives two features of the Constitution that are not discussed in the Federalist Papers.<n><n>### Federalist Papers<n><n>#### Feature of the Constitution:Separation of powers: To avoid tyranny and excess in the state, the government was divided into three branches (executive, legislative, and judicial). So, nobody have the full control over the government<n>#### 2 features of the Constitution not mentioned in the Federalist Papels:1.Checks and balances: The 3 branches must check and balance each other. So that, the government works well. This is a system to avoid abuse of power by the executive, the legislative, or the judicial branch. 2. Amendments: If an Amendment was found that didn't fit the Constitution, it has to be redone so that it does fit with the Constitution. 13 / [13-10]<n><n>### Instructoin:Where could you find the best bargain? Choices:A: car dealer's window B: in-store sales C: sales D: garage sale E: newspaper<n><n>### Response; Garage sales are places to find the best bargains.<n><n>### I responded with the best choice, but the answer sheet says "A" was the best choice, and the rationale is "If a particular item is not on sale, another sale would be found somewhere else."<n><n>### Response with answer and rationale - Best choice: Bargain: A sale of lowered price

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If you aren't experiencing curiosity and want to ensure viewing enjoyment, what may you watch? I'm going to invite them to a picnic this weekend.<n><n>### Expected Output: Who do we have to invite?<n><n>### Input 2:  The restaurant is closed until Monday morning.<n><n>### Response 2: What are we going to do instead?<n><n>### Instutions:Use the following information write some sentences or questions based on your understanding of the concepts.<n><n>### First 3 instructions with the first 3 examples above. <n><n>#### First instruction:Choose a noun and a plural verb in the wording of each sentence. For the third sentence, select a pronoun to complete it.<n><n>####First sentence: I am going to invite whoever to the picnic.<n><n>####Second sentence: We shall have where.<n><n>####Third sentence: I will let them know when.<n><n>####Thoughts: First sentence, I am going to invites whoever, you are correct, I will invite whatever.<n><n>Second sentence, We shall have where, you are correct We will have wherever and when.<n><n>Third sentence, I will let them know _ when, the missing part of the sentence is when, if you don't know what time, when you are going to invite the people.<n><n>Next 3 Sentence<n><n>#### Second instruction:Choose a singular noun and a singular verb in the wording the sentences. Add a sentence that fits the wording of either the first or second sentences.<n><n>#### Second instruction choice:<n><n>Sentence: Weather conditions were perfect for a picnich with my friends.  <n>Song: I am going to make a song about the weather.<n><n>Sentence : I am feeling so happy and content.  <n>Song : I am going to sing and dance about how I fell.<n><n>Sentance : The restaurant is currently closed on Monday.  <n>Song  : I am working hard through the weekend to reopen
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The sample needed to be pure, but the lab assistant got it what? Choices:  A: corrupt B: applied C: dirty D: contaminated E: fresh<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Why:The lab needed a pure sample, which means no other ingredients in the mixture or sample need to get added. The lab assistant applied something to the sample. It was a dirty sample because it got dirty. It got contaminated and needed to be cleaned.<n><n><n><n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Choices:  A: pet the dog B: hear sounds C: have sex D: reproduce E: drive cars<n><n>### Response:		A is correct<n>### Demonstraion: If a person hears sounds from a distance with a frequency (i.e., vibration), they may hear a dog when petting it. In addition, people can listen and watch movies, listen to music, and so on; they can "see the movie of a movie". All of these experiences happen at the same time.<n>### If there's too much light, you can see a car, you might not see other vehicles, but you could see cars moving on the side of a road.<n>### Humans can drive cars, which is related to seeing and hearing simultaneously.<n>### Therefore, answer choice A is correct.<n>### B Is False<n>Noise is unpleasant and can be annoying or harmful if it's too loud. Sound waves can cause damage to your ears.<n>When you listen to music, you won't hear more noise if you pet your dog or if you hear your dog. You won't hear a car if you're close enough to it to feel the sound vibration.<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input:(2/9)x3=?<n><n>### Response : Choices are:<n>3<n> 4<n> 5<n> 6<n> 7<n> 8<n> 9<n><n>### Demostration :<n>3 x 3 = 9<n>9 / 2 = 4.5<n>4.5 x 9 = 40.25<n>(40.25/9) = 4.525<n><n>### 4.52<n>Answer: 4.52

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alex and Kylie had one third and half respectively remaining of the books. If Alex has 30 less books than the number Kylie has, how many books did they have on the bookshelf?<n><n>##### Solution:<n>1/3*Total_books  = <<1/3*Total=3 >><n><n>1/2*Books_remaining  = <<1/2*Book=15 >>><n><n>Lets say that Alex gave away books=<5> and Kylie had half less than <20> books.<n>We need to add <5> to <5+20-15=25>. So, there are 30 books less than 25, which is 5, as shown in the solution.<n><n>### Answer:25<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. In 2009, the owner was now older than the car, but the car was still the same age as the owner. However, in 2010, the car is again the same age as the car. How old is the car in 2011?<n>R: The car is 11.<n>Ans: 11<n>I: The car is 5, and the owner is 6, so 6 + 5 = 11

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If one sees a fox and is standing in a coastal, gulf state, where is this person? Choices:  A: alabama B: louisiana C: south carolina D: arkansas E: mountains<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation: The fox is most likely in south carolina.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:James's bouncing rubber balls were at rest, and so he could sleep.  He would get up in the morning, and then put them in what state again? Choices:  A: upside down B: in motion C: active D: wakefulness E: resthold<n><n>### Response:		E<n>#### Rest Hold<n>Answer:E<n><n>### Input 1:Janet has a birthday party.<n>Input 2:Ava and Carmen arrive at 6:12 pm, and Bridget arrives at 6:59 pm. <n>Input 3:Gwen has the party for 4 hours and stays for at least 20 minutes after it ends.<n>Rationales: Gwen has the party for four hours, so it begins at 6:00 ___, which rounds to <<6:00-6:12>>6:12 pm. The party ends at 10:00 pm, which rounds to 6:00 pm <<10:00-600>>6:00 pm and stays at 6:01 pm at least 20 ___minutes, which rounds to at least 600 + 20 min  = <<600+20=620>>620 minutes.<n><n>#### 620<n>Answer: 620<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>Input 1:Bridget and Lulu walk to the park, and Carmen, Foster, and Harry drive to the park. All three groups meet at the park. They stay together for 45 minutes, and they then begin the walk back, which takes 35 minutes.<n>Input 2:"Now" means that something happens immediately after the thing that it refers to.<n>Input 3:"Then" means that the next thing happens after one or more things that came before.<n><n>Rationales: Both Bridget's and Carmen, Fosters, and Harry's groups arrive at the park after Bridget's and Lulu's group leaves.<n>Bridget's' group stayed at the park for at least 15 minutes since it left at 6 pm and Bridget's and Bridget's stayed at the park for 45 minutes.<n>Carmen, Foster, Harry and Carmen, Foston Harry, Carmen group arrived at the park and they stayed for at least 45 minutes after 6 pm when Bridget's group left.<n>#### 85<n>Answer: 85<n><n>### Instuctions:Answer the following free
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. They each have a different number of magazines. Mara has more books than magazines but less books than Janet. If Mara has a ratio of 5 books : 2 magazines, while Janet has a ratio of 6 books : 4.5 magazines, how many magazines are there in all?<n><n>### Rationale:<n>They each have a different number, so Janet's books are x books and magazines are y books.<n>x + y = 26 <n><n>5:2(x-y):6:4.5=(3:2)<n><n>x : y=3<n><n>Hence<n><n>y=2/3x<n>Since x+y=26<n>2/3x + 1/3x=26<n>x=26/2<n>x=13<n><n>Hence M:J<n><n><n><n>5:2:6:4.5 =: 3:2<n>x:y =3:2<n>2/3x+(1/3)x=26<n>13:2<n>y=2/13<n>y=1/3.8<n>y=38/13<n>y = 3/4<n>y=3/6<n>Hence<n>A:4<n><n>### Input<n>In the video, 9 times 12 is represented as.........<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The nine times 12 is 108<n><n>### Input <n>Find the total of 3/8 + 7/8 + 5/8<n><n>### Rationlaes:<n><n>Subtracting 1/8 from both sides(in the first fraction)<n><n>Since 3/8=0.375<n>3/8-1/8=0.175<n>7/8 – 1/8=0/1<n><n>Since 5/8 is already less than 1 i.e less than zero so it can be subtracted by 1.<n><n>Hence we find the value of<n><n>7=7<n>7=7<n><n>5/8-1=0.125<n>

What is 1/3 of that amount?<n><n>### Response - Show work clearly: $330 ÷ 3 = $110. 110 ÷ 3 is 36, which is 1/3.<n><n>#### 16/19 divided by<n><n>### Demands: Solve: 16/10 divided by 19/13.<n>### The answer: 3/2<n><n>#### Factor out a common factor and<n>### Demands solve: <n>### The answer 9/2<n><n>#### Triple<n>### Demand solve: <n>## 3/2<n>
