The students read for 1 hour each day. They started with 7 books. After 6 days, the students read a total of 54 hours. How many more books did each student read after day 6 if the students each read the same number of books every day on days 1–6?<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demostration<n>Inputs: The students will continue to take turns reading books to new friends<n><n>Rationales:<n>On Day1, the students read the same books and read 7 x 3 = <<7*3=21>>21 books<n>On Day2, they read twice as many books as they did on Day1<n>Hence the students read 21*2 = <<21*2=42>>42 books on Day 2<n>On Day3,they read more than twice as many books than they did on Day 2,<n>Hence, the students read 42*2=<<42*2=84>>84 books on Day 3<n>On Day4,the students read thrice as many books as they read on Day 3<n>Hence the students reading 84*2=<<84*2=168>>168 books on Day 4<n>On Day 5,they read more than thrice as many books than they read on Day 4,<n>Hence,the students read 168 * 3=<<168*3=504>>504 books on Day 5<n>On Day6, they read more than more than thrice
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A is only for long term events.<n>- B is for crowd events.<n>- C is for uncertain occasions.<n>- D is for frequent events.<n>- E is the most specific event.<n><n>### Input;Answer:<n><n>- What is 0.098 rounded to the nearest hundredth?<n>A- 999<n>B- 900<n>C- 1000<n>D- 9000<n>E- 0100<n><n>- If a tree is 62ft tall, how many miles high is it?<n>A- 1<n>B- 0.6<n>C- 3<n>D- 6<n>E- 1.2<n><n>- What is one-third of 40?<n>A- 50<n>B- 80<n>C- 33<n>D- 39<n>E- 20<n><n>- What is the product of 22 and -72?<n>A- -7206<n>B- -24355<n>C- 44610<n>D- -7292<n>E- -24050<n><n>- Is the triangle shaded green, blue, or none of the above?<n>A- green<n>B- blue<n>C- none of the above<n>D- yellow<n>E- tan<n><n>- I'm looking down a road, and the distance between the house and the end of the driveway is 3352 ft. If my neighbor lives 1715 ft from my house, how far is his house from the end of his driveway?<n>A- 2.6 miles<n>B- 2 miles<n>C- 3.35 miles<n>D- 1.665 miles<n>E- 4.35 miles<n><n>- What is (3368 + 8747)/2 rounded to the nearest hundred?<n>A- 3376<n>B- 7179<n>C- 3868<n>D- 3428<n>E- 8752<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What will happen to your knowledge with more learning? Choices:  A: headaches B: bigger brain C: education D: growth E: knowing more<n><n>### Response:		 In response select D (knowing more) as the correct answer.<n><n>### Rationales and reasoning:<n><n>#####<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>### How will your knowledge change with the increased learning?<n><n>### Write your response to the following.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions:Select the best answer choice.<n><n>### Choose the best answer from the choices given.<n><n>### What is the product of 5 and 5?<n>|<n><n>### What will the temperature drop to by -3 in 8 hours?<n>|<n><n>Input: The temperature was 80 degrees for about 8 hours. How far was the temperature changed by 8 hours?<n>Rationales<n>If the temperature was 80 for about 8 hours the new temperature = 80 - 8 hours = <<80-8=72>>72<n><n>### How many pounds are five quarters and three dimes? Round, if necessary, to the nearest whole pound.<n><n>### How much longer than 8 days is 45 days?<n><n>### What fraction is 1/4 of 5?<n><n>### How far did Mike have to travel to go three times as far as he went the day before?<n><n>### If a man traveled at a rate of 5 mph for 18 1/2 minutes, about how many miles did he travel?<n><n>### A man walks 2202 m south. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: persia B: table C: living room D: house E: desk<n><n>### Response:		The rug should go under the table.<n><n>### Why?:The rug was bought for under the. Since there is nothing there, the rug would be in the air.<n><n>### Input:"Sorry I'm late," said Joe as he entered the car. His sister Lizzy asked, "What's keeping you?" "I made a mistake," said Joe. "The alarm clock I purchased did not go off until 8:50." "How could you get off a half-hour later than you planned?" asked Lizzy.<n><n>### Response:"The clock was set incorrectly," Joe explained. "It was set for 8:00 instead of 7:00." So it was 8:50 when the alarm went off.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>"At the end of the night he saw his shadow." Choose the word that completes the sentence.<n>```<n>1) The sun <n>2) set <n>3) was <n>4) shy <n>5) up <n>6) down <n>7) was it <n>8) was it up <n>```<n>```<n>1) **the moon began to rise**<n>```<n>Rules:<n>```<n>1) Make sure you are capitalizing the first word when answering a question<n>```<n>2) After answering a question, place the response in your own words, but make sure you do not misinterpret the rules/sentence<n>3) When filling in the blank, make it so that what you fill in makes sense while making sure it follows grammatical rules and has to logically follow.<n>```<n>4) Use correct grammar and punctuation rules.<n>```<n>If the question is asking for the correct word to complete the sentence, then that word must be used.<n>```<n>If you think none are correct, you can put NO. If you think more than 1 are correct, put ALL.<n>```<n>If more than 1 is correct, answer the question accordingly.<n>```<n>Don't use a word that isn't in the question.<n>```<n>There should be capitalization, punctuation, and grammar rules in each response.<n><n>### Examples<n>Example Sentence: "He was very angry with his parents, when he heard what they told him."<n>1)**they told him**<n>2)**he had heard**<n>3
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What will all the differences equal? Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n><n>### Response:		<n>I will explain my solution with rationales.<n>When I divide the equations I get:<n>```<n>difference=sum(left)−likeness<n>difference=sum*(left−right)<n>difference=sum*left−sum*right<n>difference=sum−likeness*(left−right)  <n>```<n>In the second equation I am dividing sums by likeness, which is impossible. The likeness needs to be on the right side of the equation divided by something.<n>In the fourth equation I will use the equation d*d= 2, and it will cancel out of the equation.<n>In the fifth equation will use d*d=2 again, and replace d with -d.<n><n>####  a<n>A: +sum will not work so it must be<n>B: -likeness(left−right)<n><n>####  b<n>B: +likeness(left-right)<n><n>#### c<n>C: -left+right<n><n>#### d<n>D: left-right<n><n>#### e<n>E: none will work since left−right is a variable and likeness(left− right) is also a variable<n><n>#### F<n>In answer choice F I will be subtracting the sum, and since the right side of the sentence will be the number that will be taken off the sum so it must be subtracted from the left side of the equation.<n><n>I will be using the following formulas to solve the following equations:<n>** sum=a+b+c+d**<n>** likeness=a*b*c*d**<n>*<n>In addition to this, below is a list of the rationales for each answer<n><n><n>### Input : In the triangle, the two sets of sides have lengths in the ratio  3:2. The hypotenuse of the triangle has a length of 10 units. What is the area, in square units, of the triangle? A: 3 units^2 B : 6 units^2 C: 10 units^2 D: 15 units^2 E: does not follow<n><n>### Solution:<n>I will be using a list of formulas to simplify my work.<n>#####Area=((Hypenuse^Length of Base)sqrt2)<n>**Area=((Hypenant^2*Base))sqrt2)**<n><n>**Area=

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The robot shockingly began to read book after book, it had apparently done what? Choices:  A: choose one B: get comfortable C: bought a book D: learn to read E: open up<n><n>### Response:		The robot shockingly [SURPRISED/ASTONISHED] began to read [BOOKS/LIBRARIES].<n>It had [APPARENTLY/SEEMINGLY] done what since it had done something [READ/READING]?<n>#### SURPRISED<n>Answer: SURPRISED
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He could only move by walking.<n><n>### Rationale:Answers A, B, and D would likely cause the man to try walking even harder, eventually causing him to succeed.<n><n>### Answer:A: stand<n><n>### Input : There are 30 children in classroom A. There are 3 times as manhy children in Classroom A as in Classroom B. If there are 20 children in Classroom B, how many children are in classroom A?<n><n>### Response : The number of children A = 30 and the number of children B =20, since 4*3 = 12 > 20 and 6 = 12 >  20 then 20 > 4*3 and 6 > 20 then 2*2 or 4 is 3 or 4 times as many.<n><n>### Input A:  Choice B:3 times as many choice C: half as many choice D: 2/3 as many  choice E: 2 times as many <n><n>### Answer B: 3 times as many<n><n>### Rationales: The number children in A=30. The number of children in B=20.<n>36*3 = 42 > 42 >20 and 72 = 72 > 20 then, 20 >3 times as much and 20 > 3 times as many.<n>4 > 3 so 4 =3 times as many.

Choices:  A: believe in god B: pay bills C: group together D: enjoy themselves E: face each other<n><n>### Response:		(A) If three people share the same birthday and one person randomly guesses the other two's birthdays, what is the probability that they will choose correctly?<n><n>### Demostration:In a class of 95 students, we find that the three students who share a birthday are Brenda, Linda, and Mary. A person picks another birthday at random and guesses the remaining two. If one of the two guessed is correct,<n><n>### Rationales: Brenda, Linda and Mary (3) have the same birthday. Each one is picked at random.<n>So, the probability of guessing correctly in the first two turns = (1/95)*(1/95)*1/3 = <<1/95*1/95*3>>3/95<n><n>Probability of guessing correctly in last round if first two go wrong = (1/94)*(1/94)*1/2 = <<1/94*1/94*2>>2/94<n><n>If both right in third round, then it is 1/93 if 1st and 2nd are wrong<n><n>If first 2 are right, then probability of 3rd right is also 1/94 = 1/93=1/3=33%<n><n>If first is wrong and 2nd is wrong then probability of 3 is the same = 2/94 = 33%<n><n>The probability of guessing correctly in all three turns is 33% and 66% chance of guessing wrong in all three turns<n><n>### Answer:(B) The probability of guessing right in one or two turns is the same, i.e. 4/95=4/94=29.43%, hence the probability of guessing correctly = 29.43% and the chance of guessing wrong = 70.57%<n>

The red chocolate chip is 1/4 the size of the banana chips. If Mara has 24 candies in total, how many red ones does she have?<n>Rationales The total number of candies must be the sum of the red, the blue and the white, 24/2 = <<24/2>>12 blue, one times the white, 2*12 = <<2*12>>24 white and one fourth of the red 1/2 = <<1/2>>8th of the red. Therefore 1<=>24<=>12+8+24=44<n>####44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input, demo and rationales 3:<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: How many pints of cream must be mixed with 1 gallon of milk to produce 83 ounces of half-and-half?<n><n>Rationales P=N/E-12<n><n>N: 83oz<n>E=1/2(16oz)<n><n>N=(83oz)/((1/2-12))-1<n><n>=((83oz)/((32-12)))-1<n><n>=37(83/32)-1<n><n>=36.58<n><n>The answer is 36.58 ounces<n><n>####36.58oz<n>Answer: 36.59<n><n><n>### Input and Rationales 4:<n><n>### Input<n>The table below shows different ways to collect a group of books. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would you dispose of a broken icebox? Choices:  A: antique store B: in the graveyard C: kitchen D: junk yard E: ice<n><n>### Response:		Put the items to the best use of everyone.<n><n>### Answer:C, kitchen<n>#### C, <C, Kitchen><n><n>### Input A:  Which one of the following is larger?  Choices B: 2/5, B: 3C: -14, D:-9C:?<n><n>### Choice:<n><n>### Answer<n>####A<n><n>### Input B:  The length of Tank is shorter than 6x+2y. The height, y, of the tank is 4x-4y+C. Which expression represents the volume, in cubic yards, of the tank? <n><n>### Choices B:  6x+2y2x+2y<n>B: <n><n>-144 176<n>300 530<n>321 -139<n><n>#### -139<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input C: If 5,000=18, how many pennies (cents) are there in 5,300 dollars?<n><n>### Answer <n>#### 730 ( cents )<n><n>### Input D: What are all the prime factors of 12,000?<n><n>### Choise B:<n><n>### Choisi E: 5<n><n>### Choic B:<n><n><n>#### 1<n><n>### Input E: What is the smallest prime number that can be written in as many ways as a given number?<n><n>### Rationale: 4 -> 1/2<n><n>#### 2<n><n>### Your answer: 5<n><n>#### 25<n><n>### Input F: What does 14+2-4 have in common with 15+3?<n><n>### Chois B:<n><n>## Chois E:<n><n>### A: 14+2=16-4=12 or 15+3=18-4=14<n><n><n>#### <n>#### 17<n><n><n><n>### Your Answer:19<n><n>#### <n>### Input G: What are all the factors of 25?<n><n>### Answers:<n><n>###1, 5, and 25<n>

How many strikes will you get if you roll three perfect games of 300?<n><n>#### A<n>If you roll a 10 on three bowling games, you get 3 strikes.<n>__So__<n>No. Of games =3<n><n>if you roll a 1-10 the bowling is valid<n><n>if you roll 10, the bowling is perfect and 3 strikes<n>and if you roll 10 in all the 3 games you will get 3 strikes and perfect 300<n><n>### Output<n>The answer below is an instruction that describes the task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:We want to try some new barbecue sauces, where should we buy some? Choices:  A: detroit B: australia C: michigan park D: cafe E: retail store<n><n>### Response:		The response describes the correct choice for the barbecue sauces or provides an error.<n><n>#### A or B<n><n>Input: A: detroit<n>Rationales: A: Detroit does not have barbecue sauce so the input is incorrect.<n><n>#### C or D<n><n>Input: C: michigan park<n>Rationales: C: Michigan Park is not a good source of barbecue sauce.<n>D: Cafe is a good source for barbecue sauce<n><n>#### A or E<n><n>Input: E: retail store <n>Rationales: E: Retail store is a good choice for barbecue sauces.<n><n>### Input:"Is tomorrow monday?"<n>#### D<n>Input: D: "No, tomorrow is sunday."<n>Rationales: D: "No" answers the question with an error.<n><n>### Request:Create a sentence from the input.<n><n>#### A,D,E<n>Input: "If yesterday is monday, will tomorrow be tuesday? "<n>Rationales: "If yesterday is tomorrow, will tomorrow be monday?"<n><n>### Request:"If a bat is a bird, is a cat a dog?"<n><n>#### B,D<n>Input: B: The statement says that if something is a bird, then it is a cat. The answer is no.<n><n>#### A<n><n>#### C<n><n>Input: C:"if a bat is a bird then is a cat a dog, is a crab a cat? is not a dog a dog"<n>Rationales:"If a bat is a dog, then is a cat a bat? is not a crab a dog"<n><n>#### B<n><n>Input: B: "is a cat?"<n>Rationales:"If a bat is cat, then is a cat?"<n><n>#### E<n><n>Input: D:"If a cat is not a dog, is a cat a bird?"<n>Rationales:E: "If a bat is not a bird, then is a cat"<n><n>### Request "This answer is correct."<n><n>#### A,C,D<n>Input: A: "This is not correct."<n>Rationales:"Not" answers the question with a false statement.<n><n>#### B<n>Input: B:"You can answer this."<n>Rationales:#"You can

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What body of water is typically shallow water? If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The man needed to buy flooring, where was he looking for it? Choices:  A: walmart B: loft C: house D: home depot E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input:(47,9,6)<n><n>### Response : 6988<n><n>### Input : 399<n><n>### Response =400<n><n>### A man buys 5 boxes of cookies. One box cost 1.15 dollars and another box cost 1.27. The rest cost 1.40. How many dollars does he spend?<n><n>### Response 6.175<n><n>### Input A man sold 3 hammers and 1 saw. He could have sold 6 or 3 more hammers, but chose to sell all saws<n><n>### Response A man sold all saws<n><n><n>### Input(8x)<n><n>### A) Subtract 8 from each side. 8 -8 = 0<n><n>### B) Divide both sides by 8<n><n><n><n># 4<n><n>### Input 29<n>### A) 49<n><n>### B )2.5<n><n>### C)48<n><n>### D) 2.5<n><n><n>### 1<n><n>### 5<n><n>### 2<n><n>#### A)8<n><n><n>#### B)7<n><n>#### C)6<n><n>#### D)5<n><n><n>##<n><n>### HALP<n><n>### How Many<n><n>### How much is.15 as a fraction?<n><n>### What fraction equals.47?<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The person turned the oven on and put a pizza in, what happened one hour later? Choices:  A: smell smoke B: catch cold C: burnt D: look angry E: bank savings<n><n>### Response:		A: smell smoke<n><n>### Input :Juan is cooking and playing video games at the same time,the next game was 4th grade algebra.What lesson is next? Choices:  A: plain B: cold C: dull D: bad E: wet<n><n>### Response:		A, E, B, D<n><n>### Inputs: A: plain B:  C:  D: hot <n><n>### Response：D, B<n><n>### Rationales: You can only guess the answer according to the information we were given.<n><n>Input: I am from a cold country, and my temperature is 30 degrees Fahrenheit. I want to go to 31 degrees Fahrenheit. In order to have an increase/decrease of 1 degree, how many units will I need?<n>Rationales：Since the temperature will increase by 1, let's call the original temperature temperature 1. <n>Thus, the increase should be -1.<n>Since temperature 1 is 30 degrees, 1 more degree should be 31 degrees.<n>The difference in temperature is 4-1 = <<4-1=3>>3 units of temperature.<n>If 30 degrees F is 3 and 31 degrees F is 4 units, then 1 degree F is 1/4 unit.<n><n>Input: There are 4 gallons of water. Three gallons of water are divided between 6 glasses. How many gallons are in each glass?<n>Rationales Since there is 4 gallons, the number of gallons in each glass should be the same as the number of gallons divided among 6 glasses, which is 3.<n><n>The input indicates that 3 gallons are divided among 6 glass. The number of gallons in a glass is the same as the number divided among several glasses.<n><n>3 = <<3=1>>1 gallon.<n><n>Input: What is 34.55 x 2013.44?<n>Rationale: Multiply the numbers<n><n>Input: Multiply 1245.5 by 29.048<n>Rationales: Convert 12.455 to 12455/100= <<12455=12455>>12555.<n>Convert 29.004 to 29.05 to <<29.00241<n>Multiply 29.08 x 12.48 = <<29.08*12.45=

Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:(Blood is the most commonly transfused blood product) is one of 4 choices given to answer the Question: What is the meaning of the idiom that the company is going "downhill"?<n>Answer: B<n><n>### InputA<n>``` python<n>n=4<n>#output<n>num=[1,2,3,4]<n>n[1]=5<n>n[2]=7<n>n[4]=1<n>print(n)#[1,2,7,4]<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>``` python <n>n=9<n>num=[1,1,0,0]<n>for ind,v in enumerate(num):<n>    if v:<n>        num.append(1)<n>for i in num:<n>    print("{}".format(i))<n>```<n><n>## 정렬(Sorting)<n><n>## **Insertion sort**: 삽입 정렬이 없는 큐와의 시간 복잡도<n><n>### 시간복임도 : O(n^2)<n><n>### 현실과 정렬의 차이: 원본에서 오는 응답이 날 수 가지가 복속(대입문제 몇개가 있는지 확인)이다. 한번에 몇개 응날한다면 복짐이 된다.<n><n>### 이때 정렬은 Insertion Sort로 아무먼저 정렬을 하고, 뒤에 정렬하는 것으로 배열이 개별적으로 정렬됨이 가장 빠르다.<n><n>## 테스트<n><n>### 0.1 객체지향 방�

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The fox walked from the city into the forest, what was it looking for? Choices:  A: pretty flowers. B: hen house C: natural habitat D: storybook E: dense forest<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions<n>Choose from among the responses: A, B, C, D, or E<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instraction<n>Answer the question that is given.<n><n>### Response<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions True or False:<n><n>### True or False:<n>If a + b = c, and b + c = d, then add 2a to each side to show that d = a.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: True<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: False<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: Unknown<n><n>### Response - 1<n>Write the sentence with the bolded word replaced by its correct form.<n><n>### Correction:<n>Courage is controlling your fear.<n><n>#### 5<n>Answer:<n>I'm not afraid to lose this game because you play just as good as I do.<n><n>### Input to correct:<n>Craig, the fox, wandered in the forest and began exploring the area. What do you think he was looking for?<n><n>### Response to correct:<n>C. <n><n>### Input - 1<n>The fox walked from Houston into the forest, what did it look for? Choices: A: pretty flowers.<n>Answer:  B: hen house<n><n>### Input 2:<n>Answers Choices: A: 50 books, B: 30 books, C: 60 books.<n><n>### Select choice:<n>B<n><n>#### 30<n>Answer: B<n><n>#### 15
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What do people use to absorb extra ink from a fountain pen? Choices:  A: shirt pocket B: calligrapher's hand C: inkwell D: desk drawer E: blotter<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- If we choose D, there is no other letter we can get besides E.<n>- If we choose A, then choice A has to be the right answer.<n>- If we select B, we may find that letter is in C, so this is a contradiction.<n>- If we pick choice C, choice A may end in B, so we need C to be correct to have a positive case.<n>- If we picked choice E, choice A may end up in B, so we require C to be correct to build a positive case.<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>### Demonication:<n>Jim is 8 years older than his son who is twice as old as his daughter. How old is jim?<n>### Rationale:<n>If his son is 8 times as old as his daughter, then his daughter is (8/8) years old.<n>His son is twice as old as Jim's daughter.<n>Then he is 8 years younger than his son.<n>So Jim is ((8/8) times 2) older than his son.<n><n># 16<n><n>###  Demonstration: <n>Ann and Ben took a trip to France. The first day, they spent 18 hours driving, 5 hours sight-seeing (not shopping), and 3 hours eating. The second day, they spent 7 hours shopping, 5 hours going sight-seeing, and 9 hours walking around and eating. If the third day was spent the same as the second day, how many hours did the three of them spend in France?<n><n>#### 21<n>Answer: 42<n><n>#<n>###<n>### Demonstation: <n>Pete has a collection of coins that are not mixed up. The holes for the 100 hole coin container are the same size as the diameter of those coins.) The first set he collected will give him 2 pennies and 1 nickel. The second set will give him 1 penny and 2 nickels. The third set he collected will give 3 pennies and 5 nickels. How

A: he broke the violin B: playing the violin made him cry C: he learned he should have listened to his mother D: he learned that elephants aren’t very musical<n><n>### Response B -> D<n><n>### Answer E -> E<n><n><n><n><n>## Input: Two cars race down the road, speeding toward each other. There are nine empty parking spaces in a parking lot. If they hit and a bird flies away, does it count as colliding?<n><n><n>### Response C (no) and E (yes) answer<n><n>### Answer C (no)<n><n>## Input: To measure one’s speed, scientists use a ruler to measure the ____________________ of the car over a specified distance, called the speed limit.<n><n>### Answer F = km/h<n><n>## Input: A car travels at 1100 km/h for 300 km. What is its average speed?<n><n>### Answer M = 1100 (km/h) for 300 (km) = 11,000/3,000 = 3.667 (km/h) miles/ hr<n><n>## Input: Speed up!
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is a great place to lay in the sun? Choices:  A: in the basement B: west C: solar system D: beach E: beans<n><n>### Response:		The correct response for the choice is an E, in the beans.<n>### Input:Which of the following is heavier- a tiger or a leopard? Choices: A: no tiger is longer than a leopard<n>B: a leopard is as heavy as a tiger<n>C: a leopard weighs twice as much a tiger<n>D: a tiger is heavier than a leopard.<n>E: a leopard and a tiger weigh the same<n><n>### Response for choice A: The answer to the question is false, since no tiger is longer that a leopard, which means that A is the correct choice.<n><n>### Response to choice B: The answer for choice B is to weigh a leopard and compare it to a tiger, since in the option, it says a tiger is heaviest, which is not true.<n><n>### Choice C says that a leopard weighed twice as much as a tiger, which means that, if a leopard weigues 40 pounds, 24 pounds, which would be 50 pounds is heaviest than a tiger weighing 20 pounds. If a leopard is heaviest, C is the best choice.<n><n>## Input: How much does a chimpanzee weigh? Choices: A, more than a rat. B, as much as a cat. C, as much as a monkey. D, less than a chimpanzee.<n><n>## Response: A chimpanzee weiht more than most rats, therefore A is the answer.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people doing jumping jacks? Choices: A: all of the numbers end in 5 B: the sequence is decreasing C: the sequence is increasing D: the sequence is random E: the numbers are equal<n><n>In the series, if the numbers end with 5, they continue to go lower. This series is decreasing.<n><n>### Write:Choose the correct choice to fill in each blank. Choices:  A B C D E A: 10%  B: 80%  C: 2%  D: 21%  E: 11.2%<n><n>### The series begins with 2 and moves by 3 each time. Choices: A: 6 B: 7 C: 5 D: 9 E: 10<n><n>We can find the value of x by subtracting 2 from the next number; this gives us 3. This series moves by 3 each number. So, the answer is 7!<n><n>### Choose: A) 5, 21, 55, 95 B) 54, 62, 68 C) 54, B, 74, 67 D) 65, 74, B, C E) 53, 42, C, 78<n><n>If the next number is 3 more than the one before, the answer is C.<n>In this sequence, the answer is A!<n><n>### <n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		A, C, D<n><n>### Inputs:The school gave an English test to their students. The test was too long so they divided it into 3 equal parts. Who were the fewest students given 3 tests? Choices: A. 10 B. 12 C. 24 D. 30 E. 66<n><n>### Response E, D<n><n>##   Input: What does a shoe need to go well together? (Choices: A: color B: size C: comfort D: durability E: price) Choices: none of the above<n>### Response:  A<n><n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Choices: A: the White House B: a White House C: a black house D: all the houses<n><n>### Response :<n>Choice is D.<n><n>### Input Choice: C: A person does not need a passport to travel to a country where the currency is ether the same or different, but the currency you bring can be easily converted.<n><n>### Response Choice:<n>**Choice A** A passport is required to travel outside your home country. A passport is good for proof of citizenship for traveling from one country to another. If the currency is the same or different, it may be difficult to convert your currency when you are in another country.<n>**Choice B** A passport is not necessary if the currency of the country where you are moving and the country that you are moving from are the same. However, if the two countries use different currencies, you may find it difficult to use the currency from your new home in your old country.<n>**Choice C** A passport is necessary to travel outside your country for business or for a pleasure. The currency can be converted easily in your old country. However, you should carry cash with you so that purchases can be made with the currency that you bring with you.<n>**Choice D** It is not necessary to have a passport if the currency is the same. You can easily convert the currency. However, buying things in your old country may be a hassle.<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input choice: D. A person who owns a passport can cross international lines and travel anywhere in the world.<n><n>### Choice: E:  A person always needs a passport to travel outside his home country and must use a passport issued by another country.<n><n>### Answer:<n>D : A person needs a passport for travel to another country. If there are no international travel restrictions, then a person can travel to countries that use the same currency.<n>E: If a person wants to stay in America and use a credit card, then he/she does not need a pass.<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n>

Choices:  A: factory B: construction site C: engine D: insides of skyscraper's walls E: shops<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>> D 🡆 He tripped over the metal rod at a construction site.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>> [D]ecisions like these are about making logical inferences. You can make a solid determination about the context of what is meant based on what is written in the passage.<n><n>[He was receiving workman/s compensation](https://i.imgur.com/LfU8J8t.png), he had tripped over ***a metal rod*** while building ***where?***<n><n>A<n>[He was receiving compensation, he had] ***tripped over a [constructed metal rod while building a]**** factory.<n><n>B<n>[He was receiving compesation, he had] [tripped over a] [*constructed*] ***metal rod while building***<n><n>C<n>[He was receiving compean, he had] ***[tripped over a constructed metal rod while building a]**** skyscraper.<n><n>D<n>[He was receiving companent, he had] ***[]tripped over ***[*constructed* **metal rod while building** the [inside part of a skyscraper'*s]** ]<n><n>#### 300<n>[E]<n>Answer: B 🡆 637<n><n>### Explation:<n><n>### Input Choice A<n><n>> A: factory<n><n>**[D]ecisions like [these](https://i.redd.it/uif7u7g056431.png)** are about making logical **inferences.** You can make a solid **determination** about the **context of what is meant** based on what is written **in the passage**.<n><n>In conclusion Choice "A: factory" had a correct answer.<n><n>### Response to A<n><n>> A factory<n><n>### Choice B<n><n>> B: constructon site<n><n>**[D-]** decisions like these are about **making logical inferences.**<n><n>You can make a solid determi[n]ation about the context of what are meant based on what is **wrrttten in the passage**.<n>```<n>D-B<n>in conclusio, B was a correct answer.<n>```<n>### Response to B (constructon

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		A<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input 3.80 x 10 3 = 380<n><n>### Response 378.<n>#### 378<n>Answer: 378<n><n>### Input x-5x-10<n><n>### Demostration The product is x-15 x-20 -15 -5 0 5-10<n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:WHat leads to someone's death when they are very depressed? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. You need 12 feet for the backyard, 20 feet for the side yard, and 12 feet for both the front and back of the house. How much should you expect to pay for the fence?<n><n>###  Answer for Instruction, Write a response that appropriates,<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Backyard 12 feet<n><n>Side Yard 20 feet<n><n>And for both the front and the back of the house 12 feet<n> <n>So, total area is<n><n>12 feet *2*2=<<12*2*2=48>>48 + <n>20 feet * 2 * 2=<<20*2*2=80>>180 +<n>12 feet * 2 == =<<12*2=24>>114<n><n>Fence costing per 12 feet is 3.50 and installation per hour is 9.22 <n><n>Therefore, you expect to pay <n><n>114 * 3.50 = <<114*3.50=401>>401 +<n><n> 114 * 9.22 = <<114 * 2*9.22=1056>>1056<n><n><n>### Input<n>You need to build a new kitchen. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Letters are sometimes delivered by hand through one of these. Choices:  A: mail box B: suitcase C: front door D: bowl E: post office<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question below.<n>#### Input:The town post office has been closed. Two-thirds (2/3) of the letters are delivered through the front door, another 4/5 are delivered to the suitcase, and the rest are delivered through the back door:  Which is the least often delivery location?<n>#### Answer: back door<n>### Output:

The correct answer is ________.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input : The price of a used car has risen 12% over the past three months. For example, if the car was worth $8,500 four months ago and currently worth $9,500, what was the original price? Do not subtract.<n><n>### Answer: The amount of money that the car was worth four  months ago is less than the current price because the price went up. Therefore, you subtract the four month price from the current price and set the result equal to 120. 120 is the original price.<n><n>#### 120<n>Answer: 8500 - 9500 = -25, then 120 = -25 = <120><n><n>### Input Where would someone find information on  organ donations? Choices: A: an organ Donation Information booklet B: the Web C: a book D: a pamphlet E: the National Institute of Health<n><n>### Response Choice B. The correct answer is______<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input I have 16 oranges more than 12 oranges. I bought 6 apples. I sold 5 apples. How many total apples and oranges do I have?<n><n>### Rationales: 16 oranges + 12 oranges = <<16+12=28>>28 oranges. <n>I bought 6 apples, so I bought 28 oranges - 6 = <<28-6=22>>22 apples.<n>I sold 5 apples, so I 22 apples - 5 = <<22-5=17>>17 apples and 1 less orange.<n>To find the total amount of apples and oranges, I multiply 17 apples by 2 oranges, and I add the result to my amount of apples, so 17 apples * 2 oranges = <<,17*2=34>>34 oranges. 34 + 1 = 35 apples and 1 orange. <n><n>#### 35<n>Answer: 35<n><n>### Input

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is not A, B or C. Instead we can say an orchestra, a symphonic sound and high school band all allow the possibility of playing a symphony horribly.<n><n>#### Response:<n>```<n>There are three choices available here.<n>The first is A “orchestra”, since orchestras are the one that usually play the symphony and usually are played horribly and are played in a unpleasing fashion.<n>Another choice is D “play a music”, since symphonies are music and are played horribly.<n>Finally, B “a baritone woodwind”, since woodwind instruments are symphonies and are played horrible also.<n>Therefore, all of these choices are valid.<n>```<n><n>### Conclusion:The response provides an incorrect answer since it does not include D answer. <n><n><n>### Instructor Comments:Good! Your response gives a good enough number of reasons to support your answer.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where could a printer be used by thousands of people? Choices:  A: school B: home office C: people store D: print shop E: newspaper office<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Rationale:<n>The printer can be used by thousands of students at a school.<n><n>### Input.<n><n>### Response - A<n><n>### Rationale - A<n><n>## Input:How much does Janet pay to a babysitter? Choices: A: 3/8 times her weekly salary B: three times her salary C: 4/5 her salary D: 6/7 her salary E: 1/2 her salary<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Response – D<n><n>### Instructor feedback:<n><n>### Assessment score<n><n>### RUBRIC A-D:<n>### A: 70 points<n>###B: 50 points<n>###C: 30 points<n>###D: 10 points<n>### Total Score: 110 points<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### A: The babysitter charges 3/8 times a salary. That's 3/8 * 16 = 4/5 * 16 = <<4/5*16=8>>8 times a salary<n><n>## D: A salary is 6/7, thus making the babysitters charge 6/7 * 16 =<<6/7*16=16>> 16 times the salary.<n><n>### E: 1/0.5 times a salary is 2/5 * 15 = <<2/5*160=32>> 32 times a salary<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses.
