Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where is one likely to purchase listening vinyl? Choices:  A: safeway B: record albums C: record store D: car E: wallpaper<n><n>### Response:		 B<n><n>Rationales: safeway and record album sell other items as well, but not listening vinyl. record store only sells records, not listening vinyl. car sells listening vinyl, but it is not specifically for listening vinyl. wallpaper does not sell listening vinyl. therefore, only record store and car sell listening vinyl.<n><n>### Input Choices:  A) 60 B) 66 C) 97 D) 133<n><n>### Choices:  B<n><n>#### 66<n>Answer: 76<n><n>Rationales <n>#### 76<n>Answer: 118<n><n>Rationales<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		C. The cabin of an air plane is for living.<n><n>### Rationales: Option B: Crash : Option C: CABIN, Option D: FASTENING, E: SLOWING

Choices:  A: eat grass B: play C: kept in stables D: dominated E: drink coffee<n><n>### Response:		(Type your response here.)<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Eat Grass and  Drink Coffee   =  D + E<n>Play and  Drink Cofee= C + E<n>Keep in Stables and Drink Cofee =  B + E<n>Dominate and Drink Coffee =  D + E.<n>  <n>### ANSWER:<n>A and E.<n><n>### Answer:<n>D<n><n>### Answer<n>D<n><n>## Instruction:<n>For the following set of numbers, determine if the given statement is an appropriate expression for the given number.<n>##Instructions:<n>For the following table of numbers, determine whether the given expression is an appropriate expression for each number:<n>2,6,20,68<n>5 * 5<n>5/2 * 4<n><n>EACH row represents a new set of numbers.<n><n>##Input:<n>2,6 68<n>EACH row represent A new set of numbers. Answer in the new set to the left of the set.<n><n>##Response:<n>2 is divisible by 5<n><n>5 times 6 equals 30<n><n>5 /2 times 2 equals 2<n><n>and 68/5 = 13.Rationale:<n><n>1, 2, 3, 4, … are consecutive pairs, so 2, 6 and 68 are consecutive pairs and are divisible by 5.  5, 9, 15,… are consecutive pairs, so (5)*5 is 25, so 5 times 6 is 30, so 30 is divisible by 2. 6, 12, 18, … are consecutive pairs so 5/2(2) equals 2.<n>Answer: 2 is divisible by five and 5 is divisible by 4, and so is 68/5. and is divisible by 3.  <n><n>##Instructions for the Following Text<n>##Directions<n><n>*Each problem below presents a scenario in which you are given information about several objects and asked to answer 4 questions.<n>*Each Question lists the options that can be used to answer each question.<n>*Your response will be the appropriate number which corresponds to your answer.<n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where do you wait in a reception area for a meeting? Choices:  A: hall B: motel C: hotels D: law firm E: office building<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A)<n>Rationales:The word reception, a noun, means to welcome someone in an official way. We say that we "receptions" (Welcome, receptions) guests to a party or to an event.<n>It is a place with seating where people can wait for the business meeting. <n><n>#### B)<n>RationalesA motel or motor hotel is an establishment that provides lodging, food, and sometimes other services (as rental car, garage, or laundry facilities) for travelers, especially motorists. <n><n>####C)<n>RationalesThe word hotel was created via back-formation from the word host. The original verb "to host" came into Middle English from the Old French word hoste, which in turn comes from the Latin word hospes. The "hotel" designation was originally an indicator of quality, and still carries a different implication than that for a motel. Specifically, a "hotel" implies a clean environment, with the expectation of good service from staff, and a generally more "upscale" accommodation than those provided at a motel. <n><n>####D)<n>RationalesIn law, a law firm or law office is a business entity formed by one or more lawyers to offer authorized legal services to the public. The primary service offered by an ordinary law firm is to advise clients about their legal concerns. Law firms typically structure their lawyer salaries so that more pay is given to more experienced attorneys. <n><n>####E)<n>Rationales An office is generally understood to be a room or other area where an organization's or an individual's work is performed, but can also denote an entire building, complex, or site. A room, which may be either part of an office complex or part of a larger building, is used for one or more specific administrative, analytical, or physical functions or projects.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input (What am I)<n><n>I come up when the sun is out and never when it's hot.<n>I'm a type of fruit that smells terrible and tastes good.<n>What am I?<n><n>### Response (What am I) <n><n>Rationales : I am a vegetable.

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:How would someone feel after going for run? Choices:  A: working out B: sore C: get tired D: satisfaction E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		B<n> <n>### Demontration:<n>Input: Run/Workout<n><n>Answer: Working out<n><n><n>### Input<n>>How many people in a family?<n>### Response<n>>Family<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Family<n><n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input <n>>How many blocks on a side of a square?<n>### Response <n>>4<n><n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: 4 blocks<n><n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input::<n>>How much is $15 after 73 cents<n>### Demo <n>>$9.27<n><n>### Demontration:<n>Answer: $9.27<n>```<n># Task: write instruction that asks a question<n>Demontration:<n>Question = 'What does 15 plus 25?'<n>Rationales= 15 + 25 = <<50>>50<n>Question = 'What is the number 16 plus 31?'<n>Demontration;<n>16 + 31 = <<47>>47<n># Demo<n>Question = 'What multiplied by 14 equals 81?'<n>Demonstration:<n>14 * 81 = 1128<n># Demo<n>Question- How far does a mile go?<n>Demonstration; <n>The mile is a measurement of 1/10 of a kilometer.<n><n># Task: write task that asks a question<n><n>### Task 1<n>Input : 'What is 20 multiplied by 27?'<n>Response: 540<n><n><n>### Task<n>Input: 'What is 68 percent of 90?'<n>Response:<n>68% of 90 = 29.76<n><n>### Demo<n>Input: 'What does 167 minus 21 equal?'<n>Demontrations:<n>167 - 21= 146<n><n>### Task: write question that has one of choices as answer<n>```<n>>Is it the 6th day of this month?<n># Demonstration<n>Yes or No<n>>It is the 6th day<n>```<n>### Demo<n>```<n>How many pizza slices are left? Answer is : A
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Mary was a bad girl, but she was always open about that.  People liked her because she was what? Choices:  A: excellent B: fun C: honest D: worthy E: choice<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: Honest.<n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Here you provide both an instruction and a demo with the rationale why you choose the steps you did. The example provided should be used as a guide for you.<n>The answer to the rationale is not in the example.<n><n>Note: Write a response that adequately completes the request above<n><n>*Answer:<n><n>1. Take a sheet of paper. Do not use a pencil or your fingers.<n>2. On the sheet of paper on the desk write your response.<n>3. Do Not erase the response using your fingers or pencil.<n><n>Your response should include the following:<n>In instruction I was asked to write a response with adequately completes requests.<n>Demonstration step 3 explains how to properly write. It also shows the distance (in feet) of the fish in the pond. Which of the following statements is most accurate, based on the information in the diagram?<n><n>A. The fish are at least 1 feet apart.<n><n>B. The fish are at most 1 feet apart. (One fish is at most 1 foot away from the other.)<n><n>C. At least 40 feet separate the fish.<n><n>D. At most 39 feet separate the fish. (At most, 39 feet of empty space is between the two fish.)<n><n>E. At most 49 feet separate the fish (There can be not more than 49 feet between the two fish.) -<n><n>### Response : C<n><n>#### 40<n>Answer: C<n><n>###  Input: A dog jump through the largest hoop on a 9-hoop jumping ring. How many small hoops did the dog jump through?<n><n>### Response A: Six<n><n>### Response B: Eight<n><n>### Response C: 44<n><n>### Response D: 45<n><n>### Response E: Seven<n><n>### Response F: 46<n><n>### Response G: 47<n><n>#### 46<n>Answer: 46<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:During the brainstorming session there was a lot of talking and what? Choices:  A: obtaining information B: exchange of ideas C: sharing information D: conversation E: gathhering of information<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Reason:<n>A: obtaining information<n>B: exchange of ideas<n>C: sharing information<n>D: conversation<n>E: gathhering<n>of information<n><n>### Input;<n>The number of cars on the parking lot is three times the number of cars in the first row of cars, six more than the number of cars in row three, nine times the number of cars on the last row of cars<n><n>### Response;<n>Cars Cars Cars Cars<n><n>### Reasons;<n><n>row number car number<n><n>First row   A     3<n><n><n><n>Second row   B     6<n><n><n><n>Third row   C     9<n><n><n><n>Fourth row   D     *     (no car)<n><n><n><n>fifth row   E     6<n><n>Total       A     +B     +C     +D     +E     (6,6, 6)<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>Answer Cars Cars Cats Cars Cars<n>

Choices:  A: strain B: though C: happiness D: realization E: understanding<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:What is the median of a set of three positive numbers?<n><n>### Demons:The number in the middle of a sequence when the sequence is written in order from smallest to largest.<n><n>### Answer:The number in the center that separates the two equal groups.<n><n>### Median : [[13/2,23,27 ],[62,110,112 ],[25,33,35 ]] -> median of this set = 27<n><n>### The median is the middle of the number.<n><n>### The two smaller numbers on either side of the median are called its upper and lower quartiles.<n><n>### So the answer is<n><n>#### median<n><n>### D.<n><n>### You have just won 3,000,000 Euros, how much will one dollar be?<n><n>#### 1.2 USD<n><n>### Let's say we have a sequence of numbers n. If we add a number to each term of a sequence, the sequence that is obtained will be called a sequence with arithmetic progression.<n><n>### Let us say that a and d are the first and last terms of a sequence of arithmetic progression. So d = 1 + a1 +... + an and a = 1.<n><n>### 58<n><n>### The sum of the series with four terms is 692764.<n><n>### Which number should be added to the given series to obtain the same sum?<n><n>### b = 0<n><n>### a + a + a + a = a + a + a … = 4a<n><n>### So<n><n>#### 4a<n><n>#### a<n><n>### The question wants you to find out which number should be subtracted to get the given answer.<n><n>### Hence it should be -a<n><n>#### A<n><n>### In how many ways can 4 yellow balls and 4 blue balls be alternately selected from 4 blue and 4 yellow balls<n><n>#### 5!<n><n>### A person can make 36 different throws if he rolls two dice in two different ways once each.<n><n>### What two dice total will the person make on his 100th throw.<n><n>####

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		(b)<n><n>### Input<n><n>While waiting for the bus. A person can do what? Choices: <n><n> - (a) Sleep<n> - (b) Read and learn<n> - (c) Wrap up in a blanket<n> - (d) Check out new books overdue<n> - (e) Focus on math<n><n>### Response<n><n>(a)<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>A person can do what while waiting for a bus:<n><n> - Focus on math<n> - Check out new books overdued<n> - Read and learn<n> - Wrap up in a<n><n>blanket<n> - Sleep<n><n>#### A - Sleep<n><n>Answer: Sleep<n><n>#### B - Check out new books<n><n>Answer: Check out new books<n>   <n>#### C - Read and learn<n><n>Answer: Read and learn<n>   <n>#### D - Wrap up in blanket<n><n>Answer: Wrap up<n><n>#### E - Focus on math.<n><n>Answer: Focus on math<n>   <n>#### E Focus on math.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer E: Roadblock!<n>Sammy should be more cautious because roadblocks are dangerous to travel in.<n><n>### Input<n>You are driving a car going at 60 miles/hour on a highway. You drive 1 hour. Then you increase your speed 5 miles per hour. At the end of 2 hours, you are traveling at 75 miles/hour. How many kilometers per hour were you going originally?<n><n>Rationales: Sam is driving at 60 miles per hour on a highway for an hour, so he travels 60 miles for an hour = <<60*1-=30>>35 miles.<n>So, he is traveling at 74 miles per hour (74 mph) the next two hours since he increased his speed by 4 miles/hour.<n>Hence, he was traveling at 70 miles per hour originally.<n>#### 70<n>Answer: 70<n><n>###### Input:<n>1.2 miles per hour 2.11 miles per hour<n>5 miles per hour 2 miles per hour<n>Rationales:1.2 * = <<1.2*>>2<n>2.11 * = <<2.11*>>5.11<n>5 * = <<5*>>5<n>2 * = <<2*>>0.11<n>Hence, the total for the first three equations is <<1.2+2.11+5.11+0.22+1.2+2+5+5.11>>10<n><n>###### Answer:<n>32<n><n>###### Input<n>Sofia and Gus are traveling to a park 81 miles from their home. They drive at an average rate of 47 miles per hour over the course of two hours. How many miles per hour do they travel the last hour?<n><n>Rationalies: Sofia and Gus travel 81 miles at an average rate of [47*2] = [94 miles] in two hours.<n>From the given equation, they travel [94 miles]/2 hours = [47 miles] in one hour.<n>So, they take [47 miles]/2 hours = [23.5 miles] in the last hour.<n>Hence, they travel 23.5 miles

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		Which of the following words would be appropriate to fill in the blank in a sentence? Radio shack B: What television requires cable? Substation C: Television D: Which television requires cable? Desk E: What need requires cable?<n>Rationales; The answers should all consist of two or three words.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: B<n>#### D<n>Answer: C<n>#### E<n>Answer: B
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where is a business restaurant likely to be located? Choices:  A: town B: at hotel C: mall D: business sector E: yellow pages<n><n>### Response:		A: (town)<n><n>### Input;Where is a bus station likely to be located?Choices: A: inside the bus B: at airport C: at railway D: in downtown E: other<n><n>### Response;B: (at airport)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question (choose one).<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A carpooling program has been implemented in a local middle school. The first bus travels from a school in town 13 miles away, then stops at a school in town 21 miles away, and finally ends at the local high school. Each bus travels the same route. During the first week of school, there were 16 fewer 6th graders than 7th graders at both the first stop and the last stop. However, there were 9 fewer 7th graders than 8th graders on the final bus. What was the combined number of new 7th and 8th graders at the third stop?<n>Rationales : 21 miles - 6th grade = <<21-6th>>15 fewer 6th gradres on the 2nd stop.<n>6th grade x 2 = <<6th x 2=12>>12 more 6th graders on the 4th stop.<n><n>21 miles - 7th grade = <<2-7th>>9 fewer 7th grade on the final stop.<n>But there were 9 fewer on the final stop than there were on the last stop (the first stop was already accounted for above).<n>Therefore, there were the same number of 7th graders on the last stop as there were on the final stop at 21 miles away.<n>(21 - 6th grade + 12 + 15 = <<21-7th+6th+12+15>><n><n>### This is known as the commutative property of addition. This does _NOT_ affect the commutative property of multiplication.<n><n>176<n>Answer;176<n><n><n>### Instuctions: Answer the following question.<n><n>## Demonstration:In a class, 5 students each had 7 oranges. What was the total number of oranges the students had?<n>Input

The train travels at a constant rate of 46 miles per hour. When do they reach the front locomotive<n><n>### Response3:<n>```<n>Choice A: they always leave the front locomotive.<n>Answer: 2<n>```<n><n>```<n>Rationale: If the train was 3.9 miles behind, then it will take 3.9/46 = <<3.9/43=0.086>>0.086 hours, and if they travel at a constant rate 46 miles the first hour so, the second hour will be 46/0.086 = <<46/0.86=53.505>>53.504 miles.<n><n>```<n>The third hour it will be 53.50 km, and hence the fourth hour it will be 21.75 miles, and the fifth time it will be 10.875 miles.<n>```<n>We can say they always lose the front locomotive. Hence, Choice A will be 2.<n><n>### Input4: You are playing a two-player game with a computer opponent. You go first and draw a number from the box. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What would a camper need to do before he or she can start cooking food? Choices:  A: make breakfast B: go hiking C: pack or bag D: light fire E: grab a match<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Justification<n>(A) <<camper cooking cooking make breakfast breakfast <n><5.7>>make breakfast <n><5 >> breakfast<n><6>>cooking cooking make breakfast <n><15>>cooking make breakfast <n>A:<n>||A make breakfast | 5 || 2 2 3  //5→0<n>||A cooking cooking  | 5  || 2 2<n>||make breakfast - A cooking  | 2  || 2 3 4 2 <n>|-|-|-|||<n>||0 30|3|<n>||19|30||<n>\-|- || \-|-<n>||22|3|<n>||21|3 ||<n><n>\-|- | |- ||<n>||30-22=8|3|| \-|- | |<n>||21-19=2|0|| \-|- --------|- ||<n>||19|-||<n><n>\-||-|- \\- ||-|-| |-|| |<n>||19|0||<n>|-|- |- |<n>||21|2 ||<n>||24|2| || \- \-|-| || \- ||<n>||31|0 ---------------------|- ||<n>||32|0 |-|-| | | | ||<n><n>C) B: go hikings<n>C: packing or bagging<n>E: grabbing a match<n>D: light fire<n><n><n>B's C is packing or bagging?!?<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a seafood restaurant in the east coast of North America? Choices:  A: maine B: boston C: beach town D: coastal cities E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		Maine<n><n>### Instructions:Rewrite the sentence replacing the underlined pronouns with the word shown in the parenthesis.<n><n>### Input for first example:The person who is writing this answer should pick up the phone. (that)<n><n>### Output for first example:The one that is writing this answer should (that) pick up the phone.<n><n>### Sample question 2:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Sample question:2<n><n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question. Provide a rationale to support your response and identify the type of word that could be used in place of the underlined pronoun.<n><n>### Where should you find a seafooderestaurant?Choices: A: MaineB: Boston C: Beach TownD: Coastal CitiesE: Ocean<n><n>### Response to where should you find a seafooerestaurant:Maine<n><n>The pronoun that is used to point to something specific. In this case, Main which is a word that ends in "e" must be replaced "A".<n><n>### Input<n>The person who was writing this question chose the answer Maine.<n><n>### Output<n>The Person chose the answer Maine. Main which is a word ending in "e" should be replaced by that.<n><n><n>### In the example below, identify the type of object being referred to by the underlined pronoun, and then replace the pronoun with the correct choice.<n><n>#### Which word should you replace underlined in the given example?<n><n>### 1. Choices:  A: mediate B: have rest C: stay in bed D: run out of steam E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		E: go to sleep <n><n>### Rationales: B: Have rest<n>---<n>### Solution 2<n><n>Input:The population, in thousands, of a school of fish 4 years ago and last year were 287 and 562, respectively. If over 3 years, the population increased at a rate of 41,196 fish per day, how many fishes did thay school of fish have 1 year ago?<n><n>Rationales:Last year, the population of fish was 562.<n>4 years ago = (562 - 4)<n><n>```{= <-4-> <- * ->}<n>(287 - 4)<n>(283-4) <n>(20=4-4)<n>```<n>The difference between last and 4 years ago is 562. The number of fishes is `562 * 41,100 = 2,256,312`<n><n><n>You can make your answer multiple choices and make them easy to answer to be a fun class exercise
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:A beaver can destroy a machines functionality if they build their dam in this? Choices:  A: strip club B: pocket C: millpond D: ontario E: lake or river<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: Lake<n><n>### Input<n>This is the instructions below - you should use the same instructions to complete the task.<n><n>#### What do we know?<n>I can count to 1 million<n><n>#### What is being asked?<n>I can 233 400 42<n><n>#### What will the result be?<n>The answer must be 1,233,404<n>It needs to be 100 times 10,000 - 1,000<n><n>#### Try It!<n>Try solving it by using the techniques from earlier lessons.<n><n>#### What can help you?<n>The steps below are helpful for solving this task.<n><n>#### Summary<n>Your Answer:<n>My Answer: : 1,232,404<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What state south of Kentucky and north of Alabama will you find people playing the fiddle? Therefore, Jamie did the correct thing.<n><n><n>```java<n>	package org.springpad.example4.ch6.05;<n><n>	import java.util.Scanner;<n><n>	import org.springpad.mathlib.Problem;<n><n>	public class Example4 {<n>		public static void main(String[] args) {<n>            Scanner kb = new Scanner(System.in);<n>            int ch = kb.nextInt();<n>            while (ch >= 0) {<n>                switch (ch) {<n>				// Input:<n>				case 20:<n>			input:  Jamie wanted to reduce her 958 <n>					  waist size, but  all of her efforts <n>			          failed miserably. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		If the group includes someone playing the cello then the correct answer is symphony.<n><n>### Rationale:Symphony is the only answer choice that does not include the word music. Therefore if the group includes someone playing a cello, then the correct answer is Symphony.<n><n>## Input: Which word is associated with a house? Choices: 1. attic 2. den 3. studio 4. cellar<n><n>## Response:Which word is associated with a cellar?<n><n>## Rationale:The only choices that the text does not list is a cellar since the 2 choices are on the previous line for a cellar. This cellar belongs to the group of choices 1 and 4<n>## Answer:Studio<n><n>## Input:Which answer choice describes 150 -18? Choices: 4. 90%  of 200 5. a multiple of 10 6. a number between 85<n><n>## Response:150 -1<n><n>## Rationale:(150-18) is 132 which is a multiple of 11 and (150-19) is 141 which is a multiple of (10)<n><n>## Input:How many gallons of lemonade did Mary order? Choices:  4. 16 5.64 6. 32 7.20 6<n><n>## Response:<n><n>## Rationale:[32-16] is 16 which is between 25 and 80, [32-18] is 20 which is between the first and second answer choices<n><n>## Answer:<n><n>## Input:A farmer owned cows, sheep, and chickens. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Stanley had a dream that was very vivid and scary. He had trouble telling it from what? Choices:  A: reality B: imagination C: dreamworker D: nightmare E: awake<n><n>### Response:		<n>* C. dreamworker<n><n>### Rationales:When we dream, we can't always tell what is real and what is not. This is the job of the _dreamworker_.<n><n>****<n><n>## Solution<n><n>If you were solving problems involving the number of blocks students take to/from school, it might be reasonable to assume that blocks are being covered only to the nearest whole number. Because blocks in the real world are not normally covered or traveled to the nearest whole number, we say that blocks are _covered to the nearest whole number_. For example, if it takes you 4 minutes (1/2 blocks) to get to the bus garage and 1 minute (1/2 block) to get to the post office, you walk 1.5 blocks (2/2 blocks) to the post office. The total number of blocks traveleted to the post office is then 5 blocks (3/4 blocks).<n><n>In the example shown, 25 blue chairs were covered with 3 green, 3 white, and x other chairs. The answer is that 67 chairs were actually in the room.<n><n>For example, the number of pints of coffee was initially given as 4.5 gallon. Divided evenly then the number of pints in a gallon is 0.67, rounded to 6 pints in the gallon. The answer is a little complicated and might cause problems in the real world, such as measuring coffee for a latte.<n><n>Suppose a child had 15 books, a parent gave an additional 20 books, and they have 1/5 of the 20 additional books. The child was able to give five books to a child with only 30 books. 60 books were given altogether to the two.<n><n>We write 7 as 6.5, rounded to the nearest whole number since the child has 65 books.<n><n>We write \((\frac{1}{5}) * x\) = \(\frac{1}{5} * x\) (this is in the first example). \((\frac{10}{5}) * x == \frac{10}{2}\) (this is in the second example).<n><n>

Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:She was sick and staying in bed the day of the event, unfortunately this meant she was what? Choices:  A: resting B: sleep more C: bed sores D: missing out E: comfort<n><n>### Response:		<n>If she was missing out or missing out on the event.<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input 2: She did not miss out on the event, on the day of the event she was A: resting B C: bed sores d E: comfort<n><n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input : This group of children includes both Marlene and Jemima.<n>I:J:Rationales:I:I is a group that includes or includes J.<n>Rationales:Rationales:Ratio 5:1<n>#### A<n>Answer : A<n><n>### In a classroom there are 3 girls, 5 boys, and 24 children.  How many females are in a classroom? Choices: A: 3  B: 5  C: 24 D:27  E: 26  Answer: D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:I'm looking for alcohol and fried foods, any suggestions? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Tom has 10 fewer pieces of plywood than John. How many pieces of plywood do they have in all?<n><n>### Rationale: John has 12 + 8 = <<12+8=20>>20 pieces of wood.<n><n>Bob has 4 + 10 = <<4+10=14>>14 pieces of wood.<n>Therefore, John has 20 pieces of wood, and Bob has 14 pieces of wood, for 20 - 14 = <<20-14=6>>6 pieces of wood in all.<n><n>#### 6<n><n>Answer: 6

As a group, complete the activity.<n><n>### Rationales:Work in a group because the group is more successful compared to a single person<n><n>### Response : I want an A<n><n>### Answer : Yes<n><n>### Input<n>You need to fill in the grid and show the answer in the form, ___X_/__X__<n><n>### Rationale<n>To fill in the blank, you must multiply the 10x10 grid by your answer<n><n>### Answer<n>84<n><n>### Input <n>100<n><n>### Answer <n>18720<n><n>### Rate<n>The answer is 84<n><n>## Instructions<n>#### Please Answer: If you get a number between 0 and 1,000.00, how do you reduce that number by 5?<n><n>#### Rationales:<n>In the case of a number that is between 0 and 0.1000,000000,0,0,00,00, or 100 decimals, you can either reduce your number by dividing it by 1 or by 10. When you do the division by 1 you end up changing the number by 0.10 and when you do the division by ten and you end up changing the answer by.1.<n><n>#### Answer:<n>1. Take the original number and find the closest number that is one place value less than the original number. In the case of 100, the closest place value number is 10, and therefore 100 reduces to 100.10<n><n>2.Reduce by 50 in the new place value of ten. The new place should be.05<n><n>3.Multiply the original place value of 100 by 5. The product is 500<n><n>4. add 5 to the product 500+5=505<n><n>5. 505 converts to 0.0505<n><n><n><n><n><n><br></br><n><

In total, Alex caught 3 + 4 = <<3+4=7>>7 fish, and Alex caught the most fish.<n>Answer: 3

Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:John came to see Sam and Sam kicked him out.  Sam didn't like company.  He prefered what? Choices:  A: you B: abbreviation C: solitude D: loneliness E: alone<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input Sam was talking to her friends. What did she say is best for your health?  Choices:  A. Sleep B. Exercise C. Rest D. Food E. Fun<n><n>### Response C<n>\[S\], the sum of first \[n\] integers and last \[n\] integers \[S=\{\ 1,\ 2,3,4,\ldots,1n-1.1n,\ 1n,\ldots,n\}\]<n>\$S=[1,n,2n,1n-1,n],[2,2n+1,2n-1,1n,n],\$<n>\[P=\{\ 5,\ 7,\ 9,\ldots,1n - 5\]<n>\[\sum\ S=[n^2+n-4n],\]<n>\$P=\{\ 2,\ 4,\ …2n,n+1,\ …\n^2+\n-4\n\},\$<n>\[\sum\ P=[n^2-4n].\]<n>\$G=\{\ 4\n\}.\$<n>\$G=[\{4\n\}$
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What's it called when you have seen something through an eyepiece? Choices:  A: sights B: optical illusion C: optical telescope D: light microscope E: binocular<n><n>### Response:		The term to complete the sentence is eyepiece.<n>An eyepiece is part of a telescope <n><n>#### eyepiece<n>Answer: eyepiece <n><n>### Instructions: <n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n>#### 1<n>What fraction does 2 divided by 7 equal (answer with the fraction 2/7)<n>```html<n>- html:<n>```<n>### Answer:The fraction to complete the sentence is 7/14. 2 divided by 20 is equal to 1/20 or 0.05. 2 divided by one of the fractions with 20 as a denominator will give you an answer greater than 0.1, which is the number on the denominator of fraction 7/14<n>2/7=0.285714285<n>#### 7/14
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of jogging? Choices:  A: insect repellent B: heart attacks C: improved health D: shin splints E: being tired<n><n>### Response:		Heart attacks<n><n>---<n>### [Sample question 13](sample#q-13)<n><n>Below is a problem.<n><n>Input: Input: A and B are at the beach. They divide 84 gallons of water equally. How many pints each should get?<n>Rationales:\<n>\(\frac{84\div 2}{2}=42 pints\)\<n>\(\frac{42\div 2}{3}=14 pints\)\<n>A and B should each get 14/2 = 7 pints.<n><n>#### Input:<n><n>Input: A and B are reading together. They each took 48 books this summer. They read 64 more books altogether. How many books did each person read this summer?<n>Rationale: To find out the number of books B read this summer, subtract 64 from 48 + 64: 48 + 48 + 20 = 114 + 20 = <?....2?>214.\<n>So, how many books B read: 214/2 = <?2......?>0 B read 107 books.\<n>To find the number of books A read this summer, subtract the number of books B reads, leaving the books A read: 216 - 107 = 109.\<n>Therefore, he read 109 books.<n><n>#### Input<n>Answer: A: 109; B: 107<n><n>---<n>##[Sample question 14](sample#q-3)<n><n>Believe it or not, but in a 36-mile race with 295 contestants, there were 19 finishers. How many feet are in 36 miles?<n><n>#### Answer<n><n>15,011 feet in 36 miles<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Answer: A mile is 5,280 feet<n>15,000 miles / 5280 feet = 28 miles per mile.<n>28 miles * 36 miles = 1,008

Queen of them have 5/6 time more book than Alannah. Beatrix now is having 30 books, How many books they together have?"<n>print (input)<n><n>AnswerA = (20+30)<n>AnswerB = 60<n>AnswerC = (5/6)*60<n>AnswerD = (AnswerA /AnswerB)<n><n>finalAnswer = 60/30 + AnswerC + AnswerD + '!!'<n><n>(b/w) = '''<n><n>Input:What is a real lif example of a function?<n>Answer: (n)'<n><n>```
